What we have here is a document cast in political panic, designed with one objective in mind: to save the political skins of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. But for the majority of working people, pensioners, businesspeople and self-funded retirees, this is a budget that fails to deliver. Where are the initiatives in this budget to assist Geelong families to cope with the ravages of the GST on their income and the inadequate compensation that came through to them in the government's new tax package? Where are the real measures to lift the GST burden on Geelong's small businesses? The $300 to Geelong pensioners is, by itself, an admission that they were undercompensated for the adverse effects of the GST on their standard of living. It fails to deliver on the $1,000 promise that was made to them by the Prime Minister.

For the benefit of the parliament, I will quote from two letters that I have received from pensioners in my electorate, one of whom I will name because I know the gentleman concerned, George Vansetten, who lives in Manifold Heights. He has documented for me the extent of the GST he has paid and the difficulty that he is having on a pensioner income coping with the ravages of the GST. Before July 2000 he was regarded as a low-income earner and he paid no tax. He has had a minimal pension rise over the period to compensate him for the impact of the GST. I will not mention the name of the pensioner who sent me the other letter, as I do not have his permission to do so, but he had this to say about the Prime Minister and the GST:

quote.para: ... the Prime Minister stated on TV that the pensioner was generously compensated for the GST. This man either lives in noddy-land or is just a callous, cold-hearted individual.

speech.para: Whichever description of the Prime Minister is more apt, this pensioner has documented for me the extent of his GST payments since the GST was introduced. He has paid a total of $825.38 up to this point. A significant part of that was a payment of $567 to a funeral director's service on the death of his wife. If it was not enough for this pensioner to have this tragedy in his life, he has had to fork out GST on the funeral of his partner. When you look at the trend in that GST expenditure, you can understand why the pensioners in my electorate of Corio in the Geelong region are so disillusioned by this government and feel so betrayed. The promise that was made to them is but one of many promises that have been made by the Prime Minister and broken. The Prime Minister adds insult to injury to every Australian voter by saying that a promise that he made is a non-core promise. I was raised on a dairy farm. My father was a generous man, but he was a firm man. If I had said to my father that I had made him a non-core promise, there would have been hell to pay in our household.

We know that the other measures announced in the budget aimed at self-funded retirees will be accessed only by one-quarter of them. The worst admission in this budget is the government's own assessment that the unemployment rate will remain at seven per cent over the next year. After nine years of growth in Australia, Geelong's unemployed, along with others around the country, face a declining prospect of improving their employment status. What the Corio electorate saw of this budget was not a vision for their nation but simply a crass attempt by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to buy their votes.

Make no mistake: this is the highest taxing and spending government in Australia's history. The government is at its trickiest in trying to claim that the GST is not a Commonwealth tax. Of course, we know it is. When the $24 billion raised by the GST is counted in Commonwealth revenue, then the tax to GDP measure—the tax measure that the Prime Minister is fond of—is massively increased.

The taxing record of this coalition government is quite extraordinary. In 1996 the Prime Minister promised that there would be no new taxes and no increase in existing taxes. The public record, courtesy of the Clerk of the Senate, now shows that in his first term the Prime Minister broke that promise 63 times. That was obviously a non-core promise. We now find that that figure is up to 114 new taxes. He also promised to simplify the tax system and to cut red tape for small business. Is it any wonder that small business cannot wait for the election so that they can pay out on the government? The tax act, once 3,000 pages in length, now runs to 8,500 pages. The new tax system has been amended some 1,800 times. No wonder small businesses in my electorate are tearing their hair out at the complexity of the new tax system. This budget, the first in the new century since Federation, presented the government with a unique opportunity to lay out some markers on its vision for Australia's future, and the government failed the test.

In concluding, I might make some comment on the continuous bellyaching that comes from government members about the terrible years of Labor. Many of us here have a long political memory. We go back to the terrible years of Liberal rule when the Prime Minister was Treasurer. The Liberal Party left Labor with a double digit unemployment rate—can you believe it?—of 11 per cent. The Liberal Party left Labor with a double digit inflation rate, with double digit interest rates, with the highest level of industrial disputation on record and with one of the worst national savings performances in the industrialised world. It left it with an outdated, ramshackle, inward looking industrial base and it left Labor with a budget deficit. That was John Howard's legacy—a budget deficit in current dollars of $25 billion.

What of Labor's legacy to the coalition? We broke the back of inflation, we brought the unemployment rate down to single digits from the Liberal Party's double digit figures, we did the same with interest rates, we modernised the economy and we lifted the government's national capacity to save. The government lost $12 billion, by market expectations, on the sale of the first tranche of Telstra. They have now blown $24 billion on a tax that nobody wants. It is a great vision for a nation in a new century to introduce a tax that belongs in the previous century. That is the extent of the coalition's vision, and the Australian electorate can't wait. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: — What I have just heard is the most remarkable rewriting of history—something that no person in Australia would recognise. Those who are listening would know that, if the Labor Party is so deluded as to think that the description we have just heard really describes the Hawke and Keating governments, they have no right or no chance of governing come the next election. They will remember the 17 per cent interest rates they paid on mortgages for houses and they will remember the 22 per cent interest rate on overdrafts for small businesses. Don't you worry; they remember it now.
—You keep repeating it.

—You say we keep repeating it. Of course we do. Everybody remembers it. Why do you think the economy slowed before Christmas? People were fearful that we would go back into those days of high interest rates. They saw the Reserve Bank moving interest rates up by half a per cent at a time. Five changes in interest rates—not always at half a per cent—were enough to send waves of concern through those who were buying homes or those who were paying off loans, whether they be on farms, in small businesses or on hire-purchase for home acquisitions. People in those circumstances are very sensitive to high interest rates. Australians remember the high interest rates of the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: The budget we are debating tonight is based on sound economics and on sound success. Not only that, but it offers a sound, competent and well thought through future. It does not do the smoke and mirrors trick that the Leader of the Opposition endeavoured to do in his speech in response to the budget. For instance, it did not say that, by taking all of this money away from extremely wealthy schools—and wealthy individuals—and giving it to public schools, we are going to save a lot of money. That is 0.3 per cent of the total federal education budget. Does the Leader of the Opposition and the opposition spokesman for education really think that they are going to have much impact on education with such a tiny amount of money? One wonders whether or not this is a denial of choice. One thinks that it is an un-Australian return to saying, `We, the federal government, will judge the rights of Australians as to where they will send their kids to school.'

I have many people in my electorate, as you have in yours, Madam Deputy Speaker, who want to back the future of their children by forgoing their own. They are prepared to make sacrifices for their children. They are prepared to go without. So what right does any government have to judge whether a person is capable of paying school fees at Australia's wealthiest school or whether they want to send their children to the local public school? Governments have no right to prejudge the wellbeing of parents, what aspirations they may have or whether or not they can afford to go without. That is a matter for the parents of the children who aspire to a better future for their kids.

The member for Werriwa advanced a very interesting theory, which I read in the press, saying that the way in which the Commonwealth government has made an assessment of the socioeconomic status of people for assessing support for non-government schools should also be applied to public schools. It is a very interesting concept, if you read through it to see how it is developed. The Commonwealth takes collector districts—the smallest unit used by those surveying for a census—and averages the household incomes for that small group of 200 or perhaps 400 homes. No household is identified. The federal government, by the address of a parent, is made aware of the average income for parents in that district. So, for the first time, schools are funded on the basis of the parents' income. It is not a process where the site of the school is assessed. It does not matter whether the school is in the middle of the city or out in the bush. It does not matter whether the school is in the outer suburbs or in the salubrious suburbs. All that matters is whether or not the incomes of parents total a certain amount which will earn them a subsidy in support from the federal government, which is roughly only five-eighths or 60 per cent of what a public school student would get, on average.

The member for Werriwa has proposed that, if this process is to be applied to non-government schools, then surely the same process should be applied to government schools. When parents decide—even though they could well afford the most expensive schools—to send their children to the public system and then back that decision by huge voluntary fees to the school so that the school can have a swimming pool, playing fields, computer rooms and everything because the parents can afford to pay and because they want to back public education with their own dollars, the honourable member for Werriwa says that we should assess the wellbeing of those parents. He says we should have a look at their incomes and see how wealthy they are and we should force the state governments of Australia to cut funds to state schools where there are wealthy parents and increase them where there are poor parents. I have not heard a single person from the Australian Labor Party with the courage to carry what they claim is their policy for non-government schools into the public school area. They are not prepared to stand up for equality across the board. They will target people who want to send their kids to wealthy schools, and that is the parents' choice.

It is un-Australian for the Australian Labor Party to say, `We will judge whether a parent has a right to choose a school; we will cut funds to those schools where we consider wealthy parents send their children.' That is a judgment you cannot and should not make. Many parents in rural areas make sacrifices through no choice of their own, often because schools are not available. If some parents feel, for whatever reason, be it right or wrong, that by paying additional money their children will have a better education and better prospects, it is their decision. It has always been an Australian's decision. We have been through that argument before in Australia's history and it looks as though the Labor Party want to go through it again. What is the Leader of the Opposition raising? He is raising partly a sectarian debate. He is also raising a debate of envy. He is raising a debate about people's feelings, separation and difference within our community—a debate that has been settled long ago, and it was settled on this basis: if a person pays taxation, they ought to be able to have some contribution made to the education of their children. If they choose to pay fees on top of that funding from a government, it is their choice and nobody else's choice.

No government can stand over people and say, `You shall not pay fees,' or `Because of the limitation we place on the amount of fees you can pay, we will limit government funding so that, the more you pay, the less we are going to fund, until we get to a point where we are going to make a judgment that you are worth nothing, you contribute nothing to Australia and we do not care about your kids.' If you want to run to an election campaign saying you do not care about any kids in Australia, I think you are running a great risk, because the next question is: what group of kids are you going to chalk out of your assessment next? Are they going to be the kids in certain suburbs? Are they going to be the kids in certain schools? Are they going to be the kids of a certain ethnic background? Are they going to be girls or boys? That decision would be made on the whim of whether the Australian Labor Party feel certain people ought to be supported or not. That is un-Australian. It is unconscionable and no Australian will accept such unfair treatment. It is an Aussie's choice, it is an Aussie's decision, to send their children to the school of their choice. If they do that through sacrificial giving to that school, that is their decision.

While I am talking about the relationship between state and federal governments, it is interesting to note that Mr Aquilina in New South Wales has not been able to back the public education system in that state with the same confidence as the Commonwealth has. The Commonwealth government has funded schools in New South Wales at an increased rate of 5.2 per cent in this budget; New South Wales can only struggle to raise an increase of about two per cent. What are they doing? They are living off the back of the Commonwealth. They are prepared to let us fund their schools at a greater level than they are—at an increased level that they are not prepared to match. Yet they are prepared to take a billion dollars out of the tax system by wiping out the BAD tax. The Commonwealth government has written off the financial institutions duty and that has gone. That was agreed to long ago. The New South Wales government is prepared to take out the other tax. It is awash with money.

The states have got so much money from the GST that every state government is giving away funds for projects of hundreds of millions of dollars. One only has to read through their state budgets, whether it be Victoria or New South Wales, to see exactly how much money they have to spend. The GST is a tax for state governments, it is a tax that state governments are using. This is not a government that has played by trickery; this is not a government that has been difficult with people. This is a government that has made decisions, kept its promises and moved ahead. What we see in the Australian Labor Party are people who are prepared to play with people's education, play with emotions and promise nothing except a big gabfest about what they might do with taxation. People all the time know exactly what the Australian Labor Party has done in the past with taxation.

I know that most Aussies are aware that the economy is sound. The interest rate scare that they got before Christmas has now settled down and they are happy with the way things are moving ahead. They are backing the Australian economy and their decision making with a great deal more confidence. It is interesting to know that we are again going to have a surplus this year—$1.5 billion. It is one of five successive surpluses and the prospect for future surpluses is also good. What does that mean? It means we are paying our way. It means that every year we are not spending as much as we gather in. It means we are paying off our debts as well.

We have paid off so much of the rotten debt run up by Paul Keating—the most miserable Treasurer that Australia has seen and the person who was most inflated with his own ability of all the Treasurers that I have seen. We have paid off so much of his debt— and the debt that the current Leader of the Opposition agreed to as finance minister, I have to say—that we are now not having to pay interest amounting to $4 billion a year. That is $4 billion a year that we do not have to pay back. That is what debt runs to. Everybody who has an overdraft and everybody who is paying off their house knows what debt does: you have to keep paying it back. It is a drag on your purse week in and week out. It prevents you from having those little luxuries; it prevents you from doing the things that families plan to do; it prevents holidays and it prevents making life a lot more pleasant. That is what was done to the Australian people. A big debt was run up, and with this big debt there was a continual drag of about $8 billion or $9 billion per year out of our pockets. That payment was about equivalent to what we spent on education and was about equivalent to what we spent on defence—every year that extra cost came out of our pockets. Half of that repayment is gone and for that I am really appreciative, because that means that for the first time we are starting to have a significant impact on the lives of people.

We are able, for instance, in this budget to afford a simplified tax system for small business. We are able to support government schools with an additional $238 million over four years. Our funding for government schools has grown by 42 per cent in the time that we have been in government. It means that in our health programs we have been able to strengthen Medicare and the health system. There is an additional $900 million to improve access to primary care services— boosted, targeted funding for quality primary care and ensuring safer use of medicines. There are increased GP health services. We have been able to do all of these things because we no longer have to pay off the debt that we have had in the past. The budget supplied tax cuts of a significant nature—$5 billion next year in tax cuts. There are full input tax credits on motor vehicles for small businesses, company tax rates are down from 34 per cent to 30 per cent, FID is gone and stamp duty on share transactions is abolished from 1 July, fuel excise is reduced by 1½c and fuel indexation is wiped out altogether.

As for older Australians, they deserve it. I know that when they do their sums some older Australians get so worried about their future, but this government has tried honestly and sincerely to make sure that their out-of-pocket expenses are covered. I have spent hours in my office with elderly people, going through their accounts and looking at where the money has gone and what the GST factor has been. I have to say that, with the best will in the world, some of the things the Labor Party is saying here are just not right. We had to go through the accounts piece by piece, item by item. What so many people in the Labor Party forget is that there is no GST on food but, of course, they always add on the GST for food purchases. There is no GST on food. The compensation has been fair. I would not say that it has been generous, but it has been fair. The $300 is generosity. That is something that was not asked for—it was not expected and should not have been expected, because nobody was led to believe that they should expect any additional money. The $300 goes to people on the age pension or a part pension.

For people who are independent retirees, there is a tax rebate taking their tax-free threshold to $20,000 if they are single and up to $32,612 if they are married. What a change there has been in the taxation system for self-funded retirees. There is an increase in the income threshold for the seniors card. There is an income test of $50,000 for single incomes and $80,000 for couples for the seniors health card. Some of the benefits for people in this budget are just amazing. When people have come into my office, we have gone through their affairs in a confidential manner. It is very interesting to find that some people who expected that they would get nothing were quite surprised by the amount they receive. One instance I remember concerns a man who is just on 60 years of age and is on, I think, part compensation and superannuation. He looked as though he was not going to get anything because he is under retirement age. But then we looked at his superannuation and realised that there is no assets or income test on superannuation for people who are aged between 55 and 65. That is a big benefit to this man—it increased the amount of pension that he would receive, which would make his life much more pleasant. This budget is gradually being understood by older Australians as they come to count the dollars. From 1 July, they will have this welcome change and they will see for themselves the change that has come about.

No, I will not accept the arguments of the opposition that this budget is not good for Australia. It is an excellent budget. It is well-balanced, it builds a sound foundation for the future and it gives back the benefits of five years of hard work, because people have come out of dire circumstances and a very fragile situation. We have survived a crisis that our near neighbours have suffered. We are building for the future in a most significant way and we are not going to adopt the mean and tricky attitudes of the Australian Labor Party, or even respond to them, because our future, we believe, is an honest and sound future. As in education and as in everything else, we are building a way that all Australians can be satisfied with, not a process that adopts envy and lack of choice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —John Howard and his government are trapped in a time warp. This is not a new revelation; indeed, I have said before in this House that John Howard's prime ministership is not about the future of our nation but about the Prime Minister's past. The problem is not just that we have a Prime Minister who is stuck in the past; it is that he wants the rest of Australia to stay back and keep him company. This is a government for which time has stood still. Unfortunately, for the rest of Australia time does not stand still. Many things have changed since the 1950s and 1960s. The world is now a much less certain place, and the Australian dream of the quarter-acre block with the white picket fence is becoming less and less a reality for many Australian families.

speech.para: Tonight, in addressing this budget, I wish to concentrate, as the shadow parliamentary secretary for housing for the Labor Party, on the housing crisis which is increasingly evident in Australia. Labour market changes, especially the casualisation of labour, rising house prices in areas of high unemployment and uncertain interest rates, have led to a rapid decline in home purchase. At the same time as people feel they cannot afford a mortgage, demand for housing is increasing as the demographics of Australian households change. Between 1986 and 1996, the number of single-parent households doubled in this nation. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has decreed that, by the year 2021, there will be over one million single-parent households.

So demand for affordable housing is increasing and affordable housing supply is at an all-time low. For the first time in the postwar period, home ownership in Australia has fallen below 70 per cent, previously thought to be the benchmark under which it would never fall. Australia has only six per cent public housing. This is the second lowest rate in the OECD, beaten only by the United States. This lack of public housing has led to an increased reliance on the private rental market to deliver housing outcomes. The private rental market in high employment areas is unregulated and overpriced. In areas of low employment, rental properties are often of a very low standard.

The government has provided no incentives for landlords to invest in the affordable housing end of the market. This means that those needing access to affordable housing are faced with the unenviable choice of rents that are sometimes half their income in order to be close to employment and infrastructure facilities or more affordable rents in areas of low employment.

Added to this is the fact that this government does not encourage people to seek affordable housing. You can be breached in terms of your social security payments simply for moving into a low employment area. Many Australian families are caught in a vicious housing affordability cycle. These families have two options. On the one hand, they can live where they can afford, but lose their benefits, be breached and virtually have no chance of finding work. On the other hand, they can live where they are forced to pay up to 60 per cent of their income in rent, retain any benefits that they have while looking for employment but struggle simply to make ends meet and to put food on the table for their family.

This government has launched an assault on affordable housing in Australia. It has launched an assault on low income Australians. The sixth budget in a row by the Treasurer on budget night made no mention of the word `housing'. One would have thought that we have three essentials in life: housing, health and education. But under this government one of those strands is missing. One of the things that keep the table standing up has been removed, so that Australians can have decent living standards and have food on that table. This assault leads to only one thing, and we are unfortunately seeing it in the form of increased poverty and increased homelessness.

Figures released in November 2000 by the Australian Institute for Health and Welfare reveal that Australia's homelessness crisis is worsening. The figures show that, during 1999-2000, supported accommodation assistance programs were forced to assist 90,000 homeless Australians on 157,600 separate occasions. What is more chilling is that the figures reveal that 67,100 children accompanied adults who required access to homelessness services, an increase from the estimated 45,000 to 55,000 children who were forced to seek homelessness services just one year previously. Figures released by ACOSS reveal that the breaching of job seekers by Centrelink has gone up by 250 per cent since 1997.

This government, in these budget papers, seeks to receive an extra $212 million in revenue by applying penalties to these vulnerable Australians who are job seekers. The government is unrelenting against the most needy and vulnerable in our community. Charities are under pressure, homelessness services are overloaded and poverty is increasing. Homelessness requires a whole of government approach. This means a holistic approach to income support arrangements, SAAP, health policies, employment, education and training opportunities, and affordable housing strategies. Homelessness cannot be solved through simply increasing funding for supported accommodation and social housing—not that this government has been prepared to do that. While increased funding for SAAP is a necessary prerequisite, it is not the end of the story.

A common flaw in the way we approach public policy is that we tend to put issues in boxes and develop strategies within those boxes. We think in terms of programs, so that SAAP is quite distinct and isolated from employment services. And then employment programs are quite separate from education and training. This denies the reality of the client base and leads to the ridiculous situation where the client of an SAAP funded service is also a client of Centrelink and Employment National, but there is no will from this government to encourage these services to develop a coherent joint approach to assisting that client. In the eyes of this government, that client is three different file numbers in three different programs rather than one human being in need of coordinated government assistance.

The Howard government's much lauded National Homelessness Strategy, released in May last year, was yet another example of the government's `all talk, no funding' approach to the issue of homelessness. The strategy did not pledge one extra cent to the fight against homelessness. The prevention section of the government's discussion paper simply listed programs that had already been announced and had already been allocated funding in either the 2000 or 1999 budgets. Not one new initiative was announced, not one extra cent of funding was allocated.

In 1999, the SAAP program underwent its third extensive national evaluation process. Consultations were undertaken all over the nation, including discussions with homeless people. The evaluation showed growing demand for homelessness services and made recommendations about how the government could deal with this demand. The National Homelessness Strategy, however, simply called for yet another series of community consultations. Youth homelessness strategies under the Howard government have likewise been more media opportunity than genuine commitment to tackling the problems of youth homelessness.

The government's youth homelessness strategy or—as it has been rebadged—the Reconnect program, has now been announced seven times, between them, by the former minister, Senator Newman, and the Minister for Community Services, Larry Anthony. The 1999 federal budget pledged $60 million to the project. This represented a grand total of $1.30 per homeless young person per day. Senator Newman announced the details of the Reconnect program in December 1998, twice in May 1999, in September 1999 and again in October 1999. Larry Anthony announced it again, in May 2000. And guess what? The other morning there it was again: on Tuesday, 29 May 2001, Larry Anthony announced the Reconnect program, for the seventh time. If only funding multiplied by the number of announcements that the government made, then instead of $60 million the government would be funding $420 million. Every time the government reannounces this program, I get calls in Parliament House or in my electorate office, saying, `What's this? I hear there's another $60 million being added by the government for youth homelessness.' I think, `Well, that's good,' and I get ready to respond that the Minister for Community Services has done the right thing by young Australians. But every time I am disappointed, because it is the same $60 million being reannounced— seven times!

The funding commitment to young people at risk of homelessness can only be seen as a tokenistic response to the report of the Prime Minister's own Youth Homelessness Task Force once we look at the attacks on education, training and employment services that have occurred under this government. When the Prime Minister came to power in 1996, we had an income support system for young unemployed people that actually recognised that they became independent well before the age of 21. We had a range of labour market programs that provided accredited training and realistic pathways for young people. And we had intensive case management services for young unemployed at risk of becoming long-term unemployed. That is something the government have just discovered, that intensive case management might be a good idea, after they have dismantled all that infrastructure, all those skills of the workers who were committed to helping people find jobs in our society.

Now, all of a sudden, as part of the welfare reform review, the government decides that maybe case management is a good idea, that maybe we need that individual support. It is a bit late for this government to find compassion and to be taken seriously. It is, yet again, an opportunistic example of this government adopting essentially Labor's program, but too late to fool an electorate that long ago decided that this was a government that had spent its value to the Australian community. Those initiatives that Labor put in place were still in the early stages in 1996, but we were moving in the right direction. Working Nation was a program that Labor can continue to be proud of. By contrast, the current government is a government that makes policy on the run. More insidious is the amount of money the Howard government has cut from the sorts of programs that provide long-term solutions for homelessness.

The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is one of the greatest legacies of Labor. The first CSHA was made in 1945 and provided 280,000 new homes for Australians on modest incomes. Today, it continues its valuable role as a specific purpose payment from the Commonwealth to the states for the purpose of providing social housing. Now it is more important than ever because Australian governments desperately need to address the problem of the lack of good quality, affordable housing. Since this government came to power they have done the opposite. When Labor left office in 1996, the CSHA was funded to the tune of $1,062 million. By 1997-98, the Howard government had reduced funding to just $825 million. Much of this decline was due to the states agreeing to become part of the Commonwealth debt reduction program and pay their share through a reduction in CSHA funding. This loss of funding was only exacerbated by the 1997-98 budget when $101 million was cut from total expenditures. The CSHA has recovered slightly since, but only as a result of the deal the government did in order to pass the GST. The Democrats insisted that the states be paid some compensation for the increased costs of the GST. But when this compensation cuts out when the current agreement ends in 2003, the total expenditure of the CSHA will fall by $90 million in one year. Unless this compensation is renegotiated into the next CSHA, public housing will be a big loser.

But it is not just the Commonwealth-state housing agreement that has suffered under the Howard government. SAAP is still not funded so that it can meet current demand. In April 1999 the government sponsored an evaluation undertaken by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute, which recommended a 25 per cent increase in funding for SAAP in order to service existing demand placed on the sector. The national evaluation report on SAAP recommended that base funding be increased by 25 per cent and that after the one-off 25 per cent increase in base funding there then be indexation of funding annually to cover inflation, SAAP worker award adjustments and the impact of the GST. The government has since decided that worker award adjustments are a matter for the states.

In the 2000-01 budget, the federal government allocated an extra $22 million per year to SAAP, which amounted to an 18 per cent increase. The problem is that this has not been spent on new services. Even the $15 million per annum deal has allegedly been used only for award increases. Sector representatives have complained that, once this is taken into account, it results in only a 7.7 per cent increase in funding. Despite this increase in funding, the government has made no announcement of new services and no announcement of new beds. Departmental representatives talked of the increased funding being absorbed by new directions in programs, and award increases. Increased funding should be about growth in SAAP services: more beds, greater support for diverse accommodation assistance service models, the trialling of other innovative approaches to early intervention, and assistance for homeless people—both while they are in crisis and in their transition to stable housing.

Where the government has truly failed—in perhaps one of the greatest miscalculations of all time—has been in its treatment of permanent residents of mobile homes and boarding houses. These are the same people who are identified in the government's national homelessness strategy as being `at great risk of homelessness'—identified by the government itself. But this stubborn government at first said that the GST would not apply and lied to the Australian people. When it did apply, the government then said, `Oh well, the GST on site fees isn't the same as rent; so it's okay: Australians who live in this form of accommodation won't be worse off.' The Prime Minister said on AM that it is okay, because the GST has to be applied because of all the services provided to residents in this form of accommodation. The Prime Minister actually said that not only did these people get electricity, carpet, garbage services and everything provided by the owners but they had their mini-bar restocked.

That is the problem with this government. The government did not and does not understand that these people live in this form of accommodation due to economic circumstances. I am sure they would prefer to live overlooking Sydney Harbour in Kirribilli: if you rent a house there, in Toorak, in Adelaide or overlooking the Brisbane River, you do not have to pay GST on your rent. But if you are an Australian battler living in a residential park, you do have to pay GST. And who are these people? Fifty-three per cent of people living in mobile homes earn less than $300 a week, 40 per cent are aged over 60 years, and 73 per cent do not have paid work. These are retirees and low-income Australians.

The government's response was to introduce compensation measures in terms of rent assistance, but 97 per cent of these residents did not get one cent. They then leaked in the lead-up to the budget that this problem was going to be fixed. The member for Page went on AM on the morning of the budget and said that he and Larry Anthony, the member for Richmond, had campaigned and were going to get assistance and that they were hopeful of a positive response. Well, it shows how ineffective those members are, because the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, from their comfortable seats in Bennelong and Higgins, ignored what regional Australia had to say. The message was, `If you want to get this problem fixed, vote for Kim Beazley, vote for the Labor Party, because that is the only way this unfair tax will be removed.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002 and the package of bills before the House tonight, because they are the bills which ignite the very sensible measures brought forward by this government in the latest budget, the sixth budget that has been devised by the hard-working team surrounding the Treasurer, Mr Costello—a budget which has been very good for many Australians: very good for small business, for families and for older Australians. Of course, it is quite shocking to know that Young Labor described it on 22 May this year in this way: `It is very clear that this budget is an old fogy's budget.' We on this side of the House do not see it that way and we also resent the expression from the Young Labor movement, which is not being contradicted by the Leader of the Opposition, regarding what this budget is all about.

speech.para: This budget is all about reward for effort, about paying a dividend to Australians who have worked very hard over a long period of time, particularly over the last few years as we have worked hard as a government to repay the debt accumulated in the last five years in particular of the failed Hawke-Keating-Beazley governments. That is really at the heart of so many of the arguments that we hear from those opposite, like the member for Grayndler, whose position on so many things comes from a very sound philosophical base; but of course the practical applications of his philosophy leave many points of conjecture. There is no doubt that all of the things that he aspires to see returned to the budget may in fact have been possible to maintain in a budget position that had not been $96 billion in the red when we came to office in 1996. Over the past five years we have been able to repay nearly $60 billion of that $96 billion Beazley black hole that was left for this government to contend with.

It is interesting to note, because I share concerns about public housing myself, that, as the member for Grayndler remarked in his contribution to this debate, it is for Australian governments, plural, to meet the cost and the expectations of a most basic need and right, I believe, of Australian people: the right to accommodation, a right that many afford themselves but that some do not have the power or the capacity to afford; and we as taxpaying Australians do not begrudge the opportunity to contribute something towards maintaining a roof over the heads of those in need. But it is Australian governments which need to meet the cost of that.

It is against that background that I can understand a great deal of the angst of the member for Grayndler, but I remind him to check the performance of one government alone—the Beattie government in Queensland—which has made a deliberate policy decision to give priority welfare housing to those who travel to this country illegally. The temporary protection visa recipients are currently at the top of the list for welfare housing in Queensland. That puts great shame on that government for a number of reasons. There are a lot of underprivileged Queenslanders who are waiting for the right kind of accommodation but who are being bumped down the list by a deliberate policy move by the roguish minister Schwarten in the Queensland government to give temporary protection visa recipients this welfare housing ahead of Australians who are legally and lawfully here. People who are temporary protection visa recipients are all too often those who have been able to afford to pay $US5,000 or $US20,000 to criminal elements in other parts of the world to smuggle them to this country. They then claim, ahead of Australians, who I believe have a higher right on the list of expectations, for access to welfare housing. The member for Grayndler's points are understood. But it is Australian governments—not just the Commonwealth government—which need to contend with these issues concerned with welfare housing.

It is important to note that any of the programs that are highlighted by those opposite are programs that were cut to meet the cost of the huge debt that the Australian Labor Party's mismanagement of the economy left for this government to contend with. It is worth knowing that the budget bottom line in 2001 is rescued from $4 billion in debt interest payment each and every year as a result of this government's deliberate process of retiring the accumulated government debt of the Labor years. That is $4 billion more to spend on the real needs of Australians, not on repaying only interest on the debt that those opposite have left.

Proper economic management should pay dividends to the people of Australia. That is why the government in this budget has been able to pay for measures in today's money— not borrowing against future taxpayers' expectations—has been able to meet new initiatives, such as the $20,000 tax-free threshold for self-funded retirees above the retirement age, and has been able to meet the $300 non-taxable payment for pensioners. All age pensioners above retirement age are going to be paid $300 each, and it is going to be done in a retrospective way. This would be the only retrospective tax measure that I would happily vote for, and that is why I am pleased to speak on this bill. This $300 non-taxable bonus is paid before 30 June in the same way as the $20,000 tax-free threshold is delivered to self-funded retirees this current financial year and from this point on. Over two million Australians are going to benefit from this decision. What is best of all about that is that 18 million other Australians are not going to be burdened with a greater level of debt in order to meet this new commitment from the government.

During its time in office, this government has been very good for pensioners and for self-funded retirees. It has lifted the tax-free threshold from $5,400, which the Australian Labor Party thought was enough for self-funded retirees, up to a mark in the tax sand equivalent to the age pension, up again to around $13,000 when the new taxation system started on 1 July last year, and up again to $20,000. What this says to those who are not self-funded retirees, those who aspire to be the self-funded retirees of tomorrow, is that there is a sense of reward for the effort of putting aside for your retirement. There is something that will come your way when you turn 65. Fewer people are now going to be in the taxation system. There is going to be less worry and less concern for those above the age of 65 as far as meeting their commitments of taxation and their involvement with government is concerned. Fewer people in the tax system means that those in the tax system are going to be better served or better scrutinised, if you like, by the tax officials in this country. To liberate those in their older years from the burden of this involvement will in itself pay some real social dividends.

As well, the Commonwealth seniors health card is being extended to 50,000 older Australians. We have increased the income threshold to $50,000 for singles and to $80,000 for couples, which simply means that more people who have been on the edge of despair, not quite qualifying under the old rules and never qualifying under the rules that the Australian Labor Party left us with, are going to receive a Commonwealth seniors health card. The Medicare levy threshold for senior Australians will also be increased right up to the $20,000 level, ensuring that those in their older years who have prepared for their retirement are completely out of the taxation system up to the $20,000 level. Comments from Young Labor saying that it is an old fogies budget undervalue the real effort that this government has made to ensure that a lot of the more vulnerable people in our society—older Australians—are disconnected from the pressure and the pain of having to deal with government with regard to taxation matters and so forth.

Medicare is also being further strengthened, with the coalition providing an additional $900 million for Medicare and other health services. We have deliberately targeted areas of need in rural and regional Australia. The 100 rural nursing scholarships are designed to meet a real need in so many parts of Australia for services that many of us in the city take for granted. As well, almost $50 million is being spent on a national diabetes program. We have heard what the health minister has said about the number of people in this chamber—three people in this chamber—who do not realise that they may be diabetes sufferers. That in itself is an example of the unknown pain that may be facing so many Australians. So this program is something that is long overdue and very welcomed by most Australians.

Also the early diagnosis of asthma and the development of a care plan for patients who suffer from this disease are very relevant to people in my electorate because Brisbane—a bit like Los Angeles, Athens and other places—as a result of its geography tends to have a lot of asthma related illnesses. The effort of this government to provide additional intervention strategies for GPs in regard to asthma is certainly welcomed by people in my electorate. The increased screening for cervical cancer for high-risk women to help identify problems earlier than has previously been the case is obviously a sensible development.

As well, the new $120 million program to provide equality of care given to sufferers of mental illness is a long overdue recognition of a silent and horrible set of diseases that stalk so many in the Australian community. The lack of effort by state governments and federal governments in the past towards mental illness is certainly one thing that has been brought home to me during my time as a member of parliament. That you cannot see the pain that is within someone's brain and their mental capacity and that you cannot see a bruise on their psyche the way you can see one on their physical body means that a lot of people do not treat mental illnesses with the real seriousness that they should be treating them. I am sure all in this place can relate to those who find they have a lack of capacity to cope with stress, depression and other mental illnesses—schizophrenia and so forth. We all know such stories and we all know such people and we have all had associates and friends who have been victims of these illnesses. So the government's $120 million program is certainly welcomed by me and, I am sure, by all members.

With regard to the veterans community in my electorate, there are about 21 former Japanese POWs who are going to benefit from that $25,000 payment—not many in the overall scheme of things but each of those people is very important—and another 70 people who are widows of those former POWs who will receive that $25,000 tax-free one-off payment. That is of course also a welcome part of this budget and this appropriation bill. From 1 July, in just a couple of weeks time, the financial institutions duty will be abolished. Twelve million Australians will be saving $1.2 billion a year. Stamp duty on listed shares will be abolished, saving 5.7 million Australians a total of $675 million per year, all part of the process of returning to the people of Australia a sense of trust and doing so through their paying of less tax and therefore giving them more of their own money back. Taxes in the form of bank account debits tax, that dreadful BAD tax that is enforced by the states, and financial institutions duties are things that creep up on us all and that every one of us has to afford.

Compare and contrast what this government has done over its time in office with what those opposite did during their time in office and in particular during that watershed election of 1993 when they promised the people of Australia that they would not introduce a goods and services tax and they would not increase taxes. In fact, they were going to decrease taxes, because the tax cuts were l-a-w law, according to then Prime Minister Keating. Of course his Minister for Finance, now the Leader of the Opposition, came into this place in September of 1993 and said that in fact the opposition at the time had not pursued the then government sufficiently well enough to keep them honest on this question of increasing taxes. I and many Australians, certainly most people in my electorate, are very concerned about what those opposite might do if they were to win the election later this year, because the word is getting out there about the Labor Party's capacity to promise one thing before an election and always deliver something else afterwards. We on this side in our conduct have to carry the burden of the standards that others have judged Labor by, because this is a government that, once it has been elected, has always delivered on what it has said it would do prior to an election. In fact, in the case of this budget it is delivering even before the election.

I am concerned that the Australian Labor Party have a $3 billion tax increase plan up their sleeve. That is the difference that the forward estimates point to in this budget that we are discussing tonight. The difference between the gross domestic product, our national income, and the level of tax that is currently collected by the federal government in fact declines in the forward estimates to the tune of $3 billion. That is the sort of money that the Australian Labor Party will attempt to try to increase taxes by should they win the election later this year. Why do I know that? Because that is what they did in 1993, and the then finance minister—now the Leader of the Opposition—has said that the number of taxes that were increased following the 1993 election was of course still keeping in contact with the percentage effect of the tax ratio to GDP and they are not looking at the whole figure that was involved in the increase that came following the 1993 election.

According to the forward estimates, the tax take will decline by $3 billion over the years ahead. Australians could be paying $3 billion less in tax if this government is returned, as it continues to monitor the decline in the tax take that the Commonwealth takes from Australian workers and investors. The Australian Labor Party will increase taxes by $3 billion. What will they increase? We have not seen anything that rules out any particular increase that has been considered. Will the Medicare levy increase? It has in the past. Will company tax increase, bounce back from 30 cents in the dollar, as it will be on 1 July, to 36 cents in the dollar? That is an obvious point in the sand to start from. Will private income tax increase for private citizens on higher wages? That is something that the Australian Labor Party have done in the past and are more likely to do again.

The point is this: those opposite are promising so much in the months leading up to this next election. They are promising essentially to take away anything you do not like, whatever that is, and keep everything you do like, whatever that is, and of course not commit to how they are going to pay it. The fact that they will not commit to how they are going to pay it is a matter of grave concern to people in my electorate who cannot afford to go back to 17 per cent interest rates and $96 billion budget black holes and who cannot afford increases in personal income tax, which is government's way of saying, `We don't trust you to know how to spend your money properly; we'll take more money from you and spend it for you.'

People in small business in my electorate are also concerned about the plans that the Australian Labor Party have to wind back, to roll back, the provisions of unfair dismissal legislation in this country, provisions which have never gone far enough and certainly do not satisfy those in small business in my electorate. When small business couple the big tax rises that will come should Labor be elected with a change in the unfair dismissal laws that we have achieved as a government—they have never gone far enough but at least they have been a start—small business in my electorate know that they cannot afford the Australian Labor Party.

Small business are not the only people who cannot afford the Australian Labor Party: motorists and residents along Kessels Road know all too well what it was like the last time they had the nexus of a Labor state government and a Labor federal government. That was 10 years ago, in 1991, when the Goss government and the Hawke-Keating government conspired to take Kessels Road out of the state jurisdiction, put it into the federal jurisdiction and make it part of the national road transport corridor. Ever since then, residents in my electorate have been subjected to heavy vehicle traffic, choking on diesel fumes from interstate trucks as they travel through. The budget that we are talking about tonight has had to afford $667,000 to repave a section of Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road, from Gowrie Street to the Gateway Motorway, all because it is a road ill-designed for the purposes that the Labor Party consigned it to 10 years ago.

So people in my electorate have a good reason to fear the double whammy of a Labor federal government and a Labor state government. People in my electorate have good reason to fear for their hip pockets. People in my electorate have good reason to be justified in their support for this government's affording of the sensible measures that are outlined in the bill before us tonight. People in my electorate, of course, will be looking closely to find out whether Labor does eventually come clean on where the money is coming from for the many and varied programs, without any details, that they keep offering. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in this appropriations debate to support the amendment moved by my colleague the member for Melbourne, the shadow minister for finance. This is a budget that is very disappointing in all its facets. It is disappointing in the economic circumstances it describes for Australia and what it says about our economic prospects. It is disappointing in its lack of a vision for Australia in the 21st century. It is disappointing in the priorities it outlines. In the areas of my particular responsibility as a shadow minister, it is very disappointing regarding indigenous affairs and it has nothing at all to say for the arts.

speech.para: Insofar as it relates to Australia's economic circumstances, this budget shows—as my colleague the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said—that the GST has mugged the economy. What the statistics show, what the data shows, is that an economy that was growing at 30 June 2000 has, since that time, shown increasing unemployment, falling growth and falling investment. The Treasurer said on 21 September 1999 that the government was introducing a GST to boost growth. That is now a sad epitaph for the economic management of this Treasurer, because since 30 June growth has plummeted. There has been some attempt to create a facade that in some way this is caused by international factors and that we have been caught in some international downturn. From observing the timing and sequence of events, people who actually know the facts have known that that was not true.

For many people in the wider community, until today it has been possible for that charade to be sustained, but it has been torn apart today by representatives of the Treasury in evidence given at an estimates committee. Before the estimates committee, a specialist adviser forecasting for the Treasury said that the main effect of slower world growth will become apparent late in the current financial year—that is, the quarter in which we now find ourselves—and, more particularly, in the 2001-02 financial year. As the shadow Treasurer has been saying and as logic makes crystal clear, the consequences of the United States downturn and other consequential international effects are still to be felt. The data which we are seeing at the moment—some more of which we will see tomorrow—concerning growth in this country, data which is underpinning the forecasts in the budget that unemployment will rise above seven per cent this year, is calculated before the impact of the international downturn. I hope the international economy improves and that it can sustain Australian growth at the very modest levels forecast in the budget so that unemployment does not rise any higher. But at least once and for all we can dispel the myth that the slowdown in the Australian economy since June 2000 has been in some way caused by international factors—that impact is still to come. The slowdown has been caused by the GST and, in particular, by the GST's impact on housing, and that is what the Treasury said today. They are correct.

Also disappointing is what this budget says about this government's attitude to our economic prospects. In making that point, let me quote a very sage old economic commentator, but a very conservative one—one who has not been renowned for his support of the Labor Party over the years. I refer to Max Walsh—not one of the more left-wing economic commentators in our country, I would have thought. His analysis of the budget in the Bulletin of 5 June is devastating. I will not have time to read it all, but I would recommend it to any listeners and readers. Let me read some parts of it:

quote.para: This was an election budget. But significantly it broke new ground in its strategic focus on political gamesmanship. It was framed not only to undermine Labor's election chances but to seriously diminish the ability of an incoming Labor government to pursue its policy agenda. It has deliberately appropriated future revenue collections on an unprecedented scale.

That such scorched-earth tactics will have considerable collateral damage on the general electorate seems to be of no concern. This strategy was implemented without any reference to maximising national economic outcomes but with an over-riding priority of mollifying wavering government supporters.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: There is not even an attempt to dress up the budget as anything more than a balancing of claims of competing interest groups with a view to maximising government returns at the ballot box. And it is not as though the government has a philosophical view of where it wants to take Australia. On the evidence of the budget, it is driven solely by personal ambition, the lust for power and the comforts and prestige of office.

speech.para: Subsequently, after destroying the argument that the previous member tried to make about this government not being a high taxing government—and he does that very eloquently—he then goes on to say:

quote.para: But the future accumulation of surpluses, which were still there in the official figures at the end of last year, also presented the government with the opportunity to actually improve Australia's international comparative advantage.
It can be done by improving the educational capacity of the economy and by creating a more attractive tax regime. Labor is advocating the former—

speech.para: which is true—

quote.para: while the government has theoretically favoured the latter. The accumulating surplus was there for either strategy.

As John Edwards, chief economist at HSBC, points out, the surplus could have delivered a doubling of Commonwealth expenditure on universities and schools. Alternatively, it could have financed the reduction of the 42% and 47% top marginal tax rates to 30%. Instead it evaporated, redistributed away in the hope of buying enough votes to win the next election.

speech.para: It is a devastating analysis. There is more of the same, and I would recommend it to anyone interested.

The disappointment with regard to the lack of 21st century vision is that the strategy of this budget merely involves a series of panic measures to cope with the consequences of the GST. It says nothing about where Australia will be at the end of this decade—let alone in 2050, as we look forward. It has nothing to say about how Australia will become a knowledge nation. It merely attempts to make it harder for an incoming Labor government, should we win the election, to implement that program, as in the ways outlined by Max Walsh. But the government have trapped themselves far more, because all the money that is available to them for programs is available to us, including any windfall, in that we have the capacity to reorder the priorities with which they are stuck. So electorally it has not trapped us as seriously as it has trapped the government themselves. The serious point that has been made by Max Walsh, which is important to us all, is that it has trapped the Australian people and limited their prospects for the future.

It is a budget that shows very disappointing priorities. It supports advertising and consultancies instead of health expenditure. It supports more funding to wealthy category 1 schools instead of to teachers and poorer schools. It supports tax deductions for political donations instead of funding a GST roll-back for charities. So it is about disappointment in terms of vision, economic prospect and circumstances, and priorities. And it is a complete failure in articulating alternative policies to take us forward.

In the remainder of my time I want to turn my attention to the disappointment in the areas of my particular responsibility—indigenous affairs and the arts. The Chairman of ATSIC described this budget, as it relates to indigenous affairs—about which it talks a lot—as `modest in the short term and disappointing for the long term'. In my view that is probably generous but certainly not harsh as a criticism. After six years of savage funding cuts, this budget asks indigenous Australians to trust that this government will deliver on their funding promises when they have never done so in the past.

In the 1996 budget the Howard government cut almost $500 million over four years from the programs available to be delivered on behalf of indigenous people. They forced ATSIC, through those cuts, to make massive cuts to community training—important training programs were cut. The government now expect people to applaud because they have announced the injection of $31 million over four years to initiatives in indigenous training and employment, after they cut out $67.5 million in their 1996 cuts. They have cut twice as much as they have returned. They have made a series of funding promises in this budget, but they have merely assumed a series of promises on the never-never—that is, if this government are re-elected, they ask indigenous people to trust that they will actually commit this money in future years. They did announce $31 million over four years for better support to get a job and, ironically, to assist CDEP organisations in areas with a viable labour market—that is, the assistance is going where employment is good, not where employment is bad.

But the point I want to make now is that, for all of those big words, in this budget— which is actually the money that is being appropriated by this bill—there is only $2.6 million. There is $15.6 million for community participation agreements and capacity building, which has inherently within it quite a good idea. I am not quite sure whether it is properly implemented but—let us not be churlish—it has within it not a bad idea. However, you have to have a lot of faith that it is going to be done in the future, because there is only $1 million available and appropriated this year. There is a lot of talk for the future but not much action this year. Similarly, there is $10 million over four years for increased education and training assistance but—wait for it—$200,000 this year. I am sure those indigenous families who are hoping their children can extend their term at school are all waiting breathlessly for the $200,000 to be spread amongst them and bring great relief.

There is a crisis in indigenous housing, related to the comments made by the member for Grayndler in his speech about the problems in housing. The government has offered $75 million over four years, but it has only appropriated $3 million. There are two points to make about that. One is again that the government has not reinstated funds to the extent of its previous cuts, where it cut $80 million over four years and five years later has come back and put in $75 million. Without even taking account of the impact of inflation, that is a cut. But the real point is that in those four great initiatives—all so proudly proclaimed by the government—all it has appropriated is $6.8 million over the four years, not enough to start to address any of the problems. If a re-elected Howard government were to return, it asks the indigenous people to take it on trust that the promises in the out years might be forthcoming.

We know from the leaked cabinet document released and spoken to on television by the member for Jagajaga that not only ATSIC but the Department of Finance and Administration and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet supported a $300 per participant increase for training and work initiatives within the CDEP but that the cabinet rejected the proposal and adopted a proposal to provide all of the extra employment assistance in the areas where labour markets are strong and none in the areas where labour markets are weak. It has not yet defined what a viable labour market is, but we know that the communities in crisis for employment will not be included.

This budget promises money in the future while taking away from existing programs. One of the benchmarks of practical reconciliation is supposed to be education and training, yet the minister is promising to deliver something that his mates in cabinet are taking away through their programs. The government last Monday night lauded the achievements of indigenous organisations such as the Murdi Paaki Regional Council of ATSIC, which is a very fine organisation, and pinpointed them as ideal recipients of new government funding while simultaneously cutting existing funding for a regional training program through the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. In the words of the CEO of ATSIC:

quote.para: ... certainly the regional trading strategy—

speech.para: which is what they have now cut—

quote.para: was regarded as a success.
They—

speech.para: that is, Murdi Paaki—

quote.para: have succeeded and continue to succeed in that partnership in a way that you would not find many other examples in this country.

speech.para: Yet the Murdi Paaki Regional Council has just lost funding from that department for its ongoing regional training strategy, which initiates, facilitates and coordinates the delivery of culturally appropriate and comprehensive training programs. Worse still, Murdi Paaki will not be able to benefit in three years time when funds become available for many of the new government programs, as it is not located in a viable labour market. I am concerned that the government is giving with one hand and taking with the other.

The last thing I want to comment on is an alarming situation with regard to life expectancy for indigenous Australians. I read recently a very fine book by Amartya Sen, the Nobel prize winning economist, called Development as Freedom. In it he had some very alarming figures about how black Americans' life expectancy was less than that in many Third World countries. I was shocked to see this, so I asked the library to prepare for me, in cooperation with one of my staff, some figures about the relevant Australian comparisons. They shocked me. For indigenous Australian males, life expectancy is 55.6 years, which is way below the life expectancy for males in India, Brazil, Indonesia, Egypt, Vietnam, China, Albania, Mexico and Iran—all of those being between 10 and 25 per cent higher in life expectancy than indigenous Australian males.

The relative situation is the same for women, although the actual life expectancy figures in all of those countries are better for women. Relatively, Australian indigenous women are still lower than all of those countries. When we look at it more broadly in a region, I suppose you could say it is better news: the life expectancy for indigenous Australians is better than for people living in sub-Saharan Africa—but not much. But it is less than the average life expectancy for people in the world's low income regions in South Asia, in East Asia or in the Pacific. It is virtually the same figure for women. This is a damning indictment of us all, and there is nothing in this budget to respond to that damning indictment—no sense of urgency at all.

My concluding remarks in the last two or three minutes are going to be about this budget and the arts. It will not take more than two or three minutes, because there is nothing at all in this budget for the arts. I do not know what the two ministers do, but they have provided nothing—nothing for film, television and local production, nothing for contemporary music, no vision, no inspiration, no passion, no creativity, no understanding of the importance of the arts to Australia and the knowledge economy that we should be striving to achieve in the 21st century, nothing to counteract the effects of the attacks that the government is making through parallel importation proposals for books and computer software, nothing to compensate for the Minister for Trade putting local film and television content regulation on the bargaining table with the United States and nothing to compensate for the continuing attacks on the ABC.

There is no initiative reflected in this budget to enhance the funding of the Australia Council—its core funding or any special projects. But the biggest issue—let me just press on in the time—facing the arts is the attack on the ABC. There is no mention in this budget of restoring the cuts to radio and television drama production that are having such a desperate effect on the lives of writers, actors, producers and artists in Australia.

This is a very disappointing budget. It does not have any view about where Australia might go. It is a budget of a tired government, a budget of a government that only ever had one idea: the GST. The government is now spending its declining years seeking to compensate Australians to cope with the consequences of its one great idea, the GST—to cope with its economic consequences, to cope with its social consequences and to cope with the way in which the expenditure to compensate for it has taken away the capacity to fund the great programs that Australia's future needs. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is interesting to rise in this chamber after the member for Fraser made his comments in this parliament, crying about the fact that there are no great surpluses that the Labor Party can squander in the future. No doubt that is a bit of a disappointment because, if for some unforeseen reason the electorate were to trust the Labor Party again, there is no doubt that that is exactly what would happen. There is no use in the Labor Party talking about surplus budgets. This is the coalition government's sixth budget surplus, but of course they have no claim to fame in that particular area. If you were to listen to the Labor opposition, they would have you believe that the leopard has changed its spots; all of a sudden, they believe in bigger surpluses and less tax. But, if we go back through the history of these things, we see that that is hardly credible.

speech.para: When I first started in the New South Wales parliament, the Premier was Neville Wran, whom the Labor Party likes to hold up as one of their shining lights in the political arena. When that government was defeated, we found that there were some $26 billion worth of debts. All of the government departments that had surpluses had been raided. All the money in hollow logs that the government could find had been spent. And there was an unfunded superannuation scheme of $20 billion without a cent in it. I noticed today on the wire service that the Labor opposition in South Australia is now saying that they believe in budget surpluses. It is not very long ago that we had the debacle in South Australia of the State Bank collapse and the horrendous position that that state was placed in.

When Jeff Kennett took over in Victoria there was a $40 billion state deficit. The Labor Party in opposition cried about the fact that Kennett was selling off assets to pay off debt. Anyone who understands the situation knows that, if you are going to pay off debt, the money has to come from somewhere. You have to either raise it from taxes or sell off assets. When the Labor Party won power again in Victoria, it did not take long for us to see their true colours. In their second budget, they have gone into deficit. After all the hard work that Jeff Kennett did to drag Victoria out of bankruptcy, the Labor Party is already heading back into deficit. The Labor Party standing up and talking about bigger surpluses and lower taxes is plainly not credible. I will not even talk about Western Australia, which I suppose is the piece de resistance, with prominent Labor Party figures in that state ending up in jail.

If you look at this budget, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will find that it has clearly given back to the people some of the benefits that they should get from the hard work that was done to reduce the debt that we have in this country. No-one seems to want to give credit to the Treasurer for the fact that $60 billion worth of Labor debt has been paid off. The benefit of that is that $4 billion worth of interest does not have to be paid each and every year. That is $4 billion which can be given back in benefits to the people. I am pleased to say that a lot of that is getting back to regional and rural Australia, represented by the National Party, of which I am a member.

We are extremely proud of the fact that last year we were able to get the government to agree to a scheme of $1.6 billion going back to the states for rural and regional roads. Not since the Keating government cut off the CAR program, which was originated many years ago by a coalition government, have any substantial funds been put into local rural roads. Many of those roads were constructed during the fifties and sixties, and certainly not for the types of transport that we have today. Those roads were going back to being gravel and dirt roads because the bitumen on them was failing. No-one is pretending that $1.6 billion is going to solve this problem, but it is certainly a step in the right direction towards trying to get our rural and regional roads back into some order. The National Party was very pleased that we were able to get some money for these roads.

On the North Coast of New South Wales, people remember very clearly the hard days of the Hawke and Keating governments. They remember—farmers particularly— paying interest rates of up to 22 and 23 per cent. They remember very clearly the 17 per cent unemployment rate in those areas. We have managed to turn that around. Thankfully, we have been able to help some of the local industries up there that are producing employment opportunities. Permo-Drive Technologies has an extremely good invention that has come out of the Lismore area, which saves 15 per cent on fuel on highways and probably up to 30 per cent in fuel around the city. That invention is starting to take root. The government has been able to help that company get its operations up and running. We hope that it will have export potential. This is a world-first invention and it has great opportunities. I would like to congratulate the people in that company who had the tenacity to see this process through. It is very difficult to get anything new like this up and running, and those people managed to do that.

Aspect North, another group in Lismore which is working very well, managed to get a defence department contract into mapping Australia. A lot of our modern defence systems, particularly the cruise missiles that are used these days, require accurate mapping. Some of the jobs that have been created in that area are very high-income jobs, which is very beneficial to the Lismore district.

Five years ago, this coalition government committed funds to the Summerland Way. The Summerland Way starts at Grafton and branches off through Casino and Kyogle, up over the range into Rathdowney and into Brisbane.
