A lot of heavy transport takes that route, away from coastal areas and the very congested coastal highway. We have been frustrated completely by the New South Wales government and the Hon. Carl Scully.

talk.start.para: —A great minister.

—Undoubtedly he learnt his trade in the New South Wales Right. Some $8 million has been spent over five years because the RTA in New South Wales refused to do the plans and refused to let the projects be completed on this road. They just do not want to see that a coalition can upgrade these roads. I have said to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services that we should wipe the RTA in New South Wales as far as being the construction authority is concerned. There is nothing to stop the Commonwealth from offering to build these roads up to an RTA standard—they do have a standard for roads. We can call for tenders and we can get Aspect North, who are expert engineers, to oversee the construction of this work. It is about time we cut the politics out and got on, getting some money on the road, bypassing Carl Scully who just wants to frustrate this particular project. There is no doubt that the people of the north want that to happen. I have recommended to the minister that we should pursue that method.

speech.para: Undoubtedly, the people of the North Coast of New South Wales, which is a very high retirement area, were very thankful for the benefits in this budget for pensioners and superannuants. Superannuants in particular have long been the forgotten of our elderly, particularly under the previous government. As far as the taxation thresholds were concerned, they had to pay tax after $5,400 of income, whereas pensioners were allowed up to $11,000 of tax-free income. In previous budgets, this government raised the tax-free threshold for superannuants to $11,000. It is very pleasing to see that, because of wise management by this government, we have been able now to lift their threshold to $20,000. I am sure that members opposite will not criticise that particular section of the budget.

Even though unemployment has been reduced on the North Coast from 17 per cent back to about 10 per cent, which is a very big result, there is no doubt that it still poses a particular problem because it is always consistently above the national average in this area. The budget again shows some flexibility. Quite often there is a problem when people are on benefits and they can get some casual employment. Obviously, if they are taken off those benefits, there is a withholding period before they can come back on to benefits. The budget has taken this into consideration in allowing them to earn small amounts of money without going off their benefits. Many people who are honestly and earnestly trying to find employment on the North Coast will see that as a great advantage.

I am also pleased to see in the budget that we have managed to find extra money for quarantine. There is no doubt in my mind that rural electorates are always very concerned about the exotic diseases that can absolutely decimate some of our rural industries. We have heard debates in this chamber about fire blight in apples. Undoubtedly in recent times we have seen all too starkly on the television the problems in England with foot-and-mouth disease. I feel for some of those producers in England and the fact that they are losing whole herds to this terrible disease. The other thing, too, which we should understand is that in some of those areas of northern England there were some flocks of very rare breeds of sheep, probably very limited in number. In some instances, those breeds have been lost because of this disease. So we do not want it in this country. Because people can move so quickly around the world at the present time, it is a great challenge to countries like Australia which are free from these terrible exotic diseases to keep our country clean.

I was very pleased today that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in answering a question, indicated that surveillance in Australia has been increased dramatically. One only has to look to North Queensland where we have had an outbreak of black sigatoka in bananas. We tried valiantly to keep that disease out of this country. It would seem at this stage that we have a problem with that disease in bananas and it is going to cost us dearly. It is a fair warning that we have to be ever vigilant in these areas.

On a few occasions in the parliament, we have heard the government's commitment on defence. The Minister for Defence has shown a very strong commitment in that area and the budget clearly shows, if we look through the figures, the tremendous increase that has been put towards the defence of this country. I know that people in my electorate are very concerned about surveillance. The AWACs that have been clearly indicated in the white paper will be of great help in surveillance. We probably need to look closely at whether we need more patrol boats— something, I dare say, that the minister is watching closely. We only have to look at the entry of illegal immigrants to see that there is a need in Australia to have very strong surveillance along our huge coastline.

There has been great debate about the immigrants who are illegally attempting to come into this country. People in my electorate in particular have grave concerns about that. They see these people as acting illegally in trying to enter the country. They see that they are trying to queue jump. We have an immigration program whereby people who genuinely want to come to this country can apply through the processes and the rules that we have. People in my electorate are very concerned about the fact that there appear to be groups of people who are paying to try to bypass the system to come to this country. It causes no end of trouble, as we have seen in many instances across the country. The fact is that, if people disappear into the community, they are very hard to find again. I dare say the community does not realise that we probably have more illegal immigrants attempting to come in through our airports than we have coming in on boats. It is a real issue in Australia. We also have tens of thousands of people who are in this country illegally—they have come in and they have overstayed their visas. It proves the point that it is very difficult to control this particular area once people are out in the community. We have people who are prepared to protect them so that they are not caught by the immigration authorities. That makes it more difficult for the minister in trying to police this area.

I would also like to speak about the commitment to the Natural Heritage Trust. This was an initiative by this coalition government and it is going to be continued. There has been some tremendous work done in this particular area. Let me take you to an issue that is of concern to many people, fishermen and environmentalists but also farmers, on the North Coast—it is an issue for many countries around the world, not just for Australia—and that is acid sulphate soils. Acid sulphate soils occur where the land has been inundated by salt over a long period of time. With oxidisation and heavy rainfall we get sulphuric acid being poured into the rivers and streams. This can cause enormous problems for aquatic life and really does need to be controlled. I dare say I can claim some credit for addressing this problem, because it presented itself when I was Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries in New South Wales. I set up a committee made up of amateur fishermen, professional fishermen, land-holders and environmentalists along with Professor White from Sydney University to address this particular problem.

Through the Natural Heritage Trust we have been able to inject a considerable amount of funds into this project. I note, by the way, that every time the funds are allocated the New South Wales government comes out and announces them. Of course, that is our system of government under the federal system, and we will not worry too much about that. The funds are going to very good areas. As a result of the cooperation—and it has been very good cooperation—between the amateur fishermen, the professional fishermen and the farmers they have been able to alleviate this problem of acid sulphate soils. As a result of the research that has been done by Sydney University, some land management practices have been put in place, the run-off from these areas has been very much reduced and the problems are being alleviated.

In my final minute or so I would like to talk about telecommunications. To plagiarise a phrase from Martin Luther King, `I have a dream' that we can take telecommunications across Australia—a local call at the same speed at the same cost right across Australia. I do not think it is an impossible dream. If ever in my lifetime I have seen an opportunity for decentralisation, this is the opportunity. Decentralisation is probably one of the most hackneyed terms in Australian politics. It has been talked about, but unless you have a market and a raw material you cannot achieve decentralisation. In this instance, we have the technology available that puts rural and regional Australia on the same footing as Pitt Street, Sydney, because the regions can have the same access to the same technology. Businesses can be run probably cheaper in rural and regional Australia because there are not the overheads that we have in the CBDs of our capital cities. If we can achieve one thing, that would be something that is worth achieving. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is always interesting to listen to the National Party members when they come into the House and make speeches about things, because what they say is always wrapped up in waffle and things like `I had a dream' and I had this and I had that. It was amazing to hear the previous speaker, the member for Page, who represents the North Coast of New South Wales like you do, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, talk about how he wanted to see a sort of single call zone all across Australia. There is only one problem with that: you are the lot who want to sell the telephone company. If you are ever going to have a chance to have a world-class telephone system here in Australia, you do not do it by selling the telephone company. All this week the Prime Minister has been slashing his wrists and gnashing his teeth about how terrible it is when telephone companies go bust. We saw a telephone company go bust this week. They were only a reseller, but they called themselves a telephone company. They had a spectrum licence and they were trying to pretend that they were a baby Bell.

speech.para: This government wants to sell Telstra and what the people in the country have to understand is that all this tripe that the government are going on about—about how they will not sell Telstra until the standards are met—is not the truth. When the government sells Telstra, the standards will fall. Someone would have told you six months ago that any business that the Packers and the Murdochs invested in was a licence to print money. But the Packers and the Murdochs have lost nearly $1 billion in the collapse of One.Tel. These private telephone companies are not real smart. The National Party members who try to convince people in the bush that a privatised Telstra would help them have a better opportunity are not telling the truth. Someone standing up here in the parliament and trying to suggest that a private telephone company will turn Australia into a single call zone might be right, but it will cost you $2 a call. That is the sort of stupid pie-in-the-sky stuff that the National Party will try to sell you. But that stupid pie-in-the-sky stuff is pretty typical of this budget.

In fact, at about this time last year I remember getting to my feet to talk about the last budget. I recall that I said then that that budget was unexciting and that even the word `banal' was flattering when used to describe it, but what I particularly remember saying was that there was little or no vision in the so-called priorities of the budget—in effect, that the last budget was a dog. If the last budget was a dog, this budget is `best in show'. What do we have this year? Not surprisingly from this government, we have another budget with little or no vision. I suppose some people may have expected a glimmer of vision in an election year. But not even in an election year do we get any vision from this Prime Minister and Treasurer. We have a consistently limited vision government which trots out a few short-term measures, dares to call it a budget and hopes that it will get it over the line during the election campaign. Even the short-term measures are not quite as good as they appeared to be when they were announced on budget night.

As always with this oh-so-clever government, you have to read the fine print because the devil is certainly in the detail—that is, if it has been written of course, because often the bureaucracy does not have the chance to work out the way through all the fine nuances that its tricky political masters have in mind. The paperwork—the forms that have to be filled in and the criteria that have to be met in order to qualify for assistance—has often not been devised by the time the announcements are made. All the small business people who are still struggling under the business activity statement understand the truth of that remark.

`Trick' is the other word that comes to mind when you consider the budget measures. It is certainly the word that comes to mind when you look at the smug faces on members opposite. They think that they can buy approval by giving a few goodies to some sectors of the community that they have done over in the past. It is like, `We'll take $10 off you and we'll give you $5 back, and you should be happy that we've only robbed you of half as much.' But even those few goodies have conditions attached to them that only a limited number of the apparent chosen will be able to meet. So even in its seeming generosity to the selected target groups the government cannot resist the temptation to be tricky. Today in question time my colleague from South Australia revealed the disgraceful trickery in the government's dealing with the ex-prisoners of war bonus—the $25,000 that they gave to ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese. There was even a string attached to that. If they put it in the bank they would get caught up in the deeming rules. Even with people who were prisoners of war, the government could not give a no strings attached benefit—there had to be a clawback.

The government still have not learnt from previous experience, such as the disappointment of older Australians who thought that they were going to get the savings bonus after last year's budget and then discovered that that was not necessarily so. In fact, just last week a constituent of mine contacted my office about the savings bonus. This fellow had received the handsome amount of $39.60. He heard on budget night that he was going to get $1,000, but he only got $39.60. He thought, `Well, that's a bit of a burnt stick in the eye but at least it's something.' That was until recently. He has been asked to repay the amount. He apparently should have received nothing. So what they give with one hand they take away with the other. Goodness knows how much time and effort were expended by Centrelink, or whoever it was, to recover the $39.60 from the fellow. It probably cost them more to get the money back.

We all know that his case is not unique. Lots of people have been, to put it bluntly, stuffed up regarding eligibility for this bonus. Who can forget seeing on television the man who bailed up the Prime Minister recently on the Central Coast. It reminded me of the sort of push and shove that we had in the schoolyard when we were kids, with the Prime Minister saying, `I didn't!' and the man saying, `You did!' It is not very edifying to see the Prime Minister arguing the point with a very obviously disaffected older person. The Prime Minister, at times described as a great debater by some, was like a small child arguing the point and being determined to try and have the last word. The trouble was that the fellow on the Central Coast was right. The government had everybody believe on budget night 12 months ago that people were going to get the savings bonus. Like my constituent, some of them did not get the $1,000, and whatever they got they were asked to hand back.

Those in the government do not seem to remember the debacles of the last budget. They must be slow learners. I stress that I am talking about the government here. The older Australians are not slow learners—they are all too well aware of what they are really getting from this government: nothing or nothing much at the very best. But the government obviously still thinks it can get away with trickery; otherwise it would not be persisting with measures that appear at first glance to be straightforward and unconditional but which turn out to have strings attached.

Let me go into a bit more detail about the measures for older Australians that are supposed to be in the budget. There is $300 to be paid as a lump sum—a non-taxable amount—to each person who receives a pension or a part pension. This is what the Treasurer said in his budget speech but he did add, quietly, that this covers qualifying people with incomes up to $29,263 for a single person and $48,880 for a couple. It seems straightforward, doesn't it? But what we were then told subsequent to the budget speech was that men have to be over 65 to qualify and women have to be over 61½. The government even had the cheek to include in the budget speech the comment that any delay by the opposition would mean that the payment could not be made this month. The opposition were not going to oppose it. We are not opposed to pensioners getting $300—we hoped that they would all get the $300—but we know, because of the performance of this government, that they will not all get the $300. Obviously the government and the Treasurer thought that we were going to say no to that. That is a nonsense. While I may think that $300 is too little too late and restricted to too few, I would not try to stop it. It is better than nothing, but not enough people got it. The implied threat in the Treasurer's words that the opposition might knock the amount back was just bullying at its worst. The opposition is not mean spirited like the government is and we are not tricky like the government is.

Another measure supposed to assist older Australians comes in the guise of a tax cut for qualifying single self-funded retirees and age pensioners. Those who listened to the Treasurer on budget night could be excused for thinking that they had a tax-free threshold of $20,000 in the current financial year. The previous speaker said that he thought that was terrific and that the opposition would not oppose it, we would not knock it. Of course, we would not knock that, and we wish it was true. But it is another one of the trickeries. What they have picked up again is something like the $300 gift. The word `qualifying' was used, and therein lies the let-out for the government. The effective tax-free threshold is actually achieved by including in the calculations increases to the maximum low income age pension rebate for self-funded retirees and pensioner rebate for age pensioners. The rebates offset the tax liability applicable to private income—up to $20,000 for a single person and $32,612 for couples. So, you see, the government has done it again. It has made the grand announcement, but when you carefully check all the words you find that the grand announcement is not quite what it seemed at first glance, and in many instances is not what it was said to be.

Another condition which came to light soon after the budget was announced is the age barrier. To be considered an older Australian for this particular measure you have to be of age pension age. So self-funded retirees who thought they were going to get this benefit and who are below the age pension age—and I can assure you that there are a lot of them—are not covered by the measure. By the time all the conditions are met, there are very few older Australians who will receive the $300—I would suspect not as many as received even part of the savings bonus that the government announced last year.

Even the government members understand what this trickery is all about. Indeed, the member for Riverina, in her contribution— and she is a government member, not one of us—has publicly commented on the reaction of older retirees to the unfairness of the way this group of people has been treated—ignored would probably be the best word to describe it. She actually said that she felt sorry for the 55 to 65 year age group who did not benefit from the `lift' in the tax-free threshold to $20,000 for self-funded retirees. What a pity that she was not able to have some influence on her colleagues in government. But it is refreshing to note that at least the voice of dissidence is allowed in the government and that at least others recognise what the opposition recognised, which is that the government is just being far too tricky. The member for Riverina should get real. She should be trying to get out there and get something done rather than just saying how sorry she is that this happened. Obviously some messages do not get put across too well in the party room. The coalition party room might be the only place in Australia where people have not yet woken up to the fact that this is a `smoke and mirrors' budget, a product of a very, very mean government.

Another issue in the budget that is creating havoc is the changes in the availability of cholesterol lowering drugs. Budget Paper No. 1 says that the government will clarify Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme instructions issued to prescribers for the use of cholesterol lowering medicines to ensure that these medicines are used by people most likely to benefit from them. These changes are estimated to save $103.9 million over four years by reducing the so-called unnecessary use of the medicines. What is obvious here is that there is going to be a reduction in the prescription of these drugs so that some of those who have been taking the drug will no longer be prescribed it or will be prescribed a lesser amount. Whichever way it is managed, the proposed measure is causing a great deal of consternation to those Australians who have been prescribed the drug in the past. The Prime Minister has not helped anyone on this. His patronising and insulting performance at question time two days after the budget speech just showed what the government thinks of people who are sick in this country. In fact, his performance angered many who have high cholesterol levels despite having healthy diets and taking exercise. His reply to a question from the Leader of the Opposition revealed his ignorance about cholesterol and an incredible lack of sympathy for those unfortunate enough, for whatever reason, to have high levels requiring medication. The Prime Minister managed to insult the medical profession by implying that it inappropriately prescribed these drugs and to show remarkable insensitivity to those who have heart disease.

As we discovered during Senate estimates committee hearings, a recent study has shown that some patients have been stopping their treatment early and that there has therefore been a misunderstanding of the place or the use of cholesterol lowering agents in the overall management of high cholesterol. This may be so, but to announce this measure without reassuring people who genuinely need these drugs that they will still be available to them, and to imply that those who have been taking these drugs do not necessarily need them, was disgraceful and alarmist on the part of the government. The government has estimated that it will save a lot of money through this measure. It will be interesting to see just how much it does save. I imagine that the medical profession is not very impressed by this measure insofar as it reflects on them. And their patients are certainly looking with some trepidation at what the doctors will be able to do for them. The government is implying that doctors have been overprescribing these drugs and not adequately explaining the general management of cholesterol levels to their patients. I wonder how the government would react if the medical profession started telling it how it could do its job and thereby make some savings! We have seen the health minister running his campaign against the AMA, of which he is a member, in the last few weeks. He was very keen to try to save government money by making sure that we do not provide drugs to sick people, but he is willing to put at risk hundreds of thousands of dollars of the Commonwealth's money in a defamation matter that he is running with the president of the AMA just because he is too mean and tricky to say he is sorry for insulting her.

This budget has selected a few areas to give some increased funding to, but it has ignored many other areas. There is nothing in the budget for young Australians, particularly those who are unemployed or struggling to make the transition from school to work or study and independent living. The government continues to demonstrate its short-sightedness when it comes to young people in the community. The young are our future; they need to be nurtured and encouraged. They need and look for leadership from the government, and this government seems incapable of offering any inspired leadership to our young people. There is nothing in this budget to assist the young unemployed, to give them any encouragement or hope that they can obtain employment.

There is nothing in this budget for young families, nothing to help with child care, little to assist with the care of the aged and those with disabilities. Taking aged care as an example, while funds are being made available for standards monitoring and complaint resolution, we are not seeing anything to fix the cause of the problem; we are not seeing any more beds. The government is looking at the symptoms but not addressing the actual problem of the growing shortage of aged care services or the pressure on funding and quality of care. We have seen today in this House the disgraceful behaviour of that Millie Phillips woman and the Yagoona Nursing Home. This is a person who is running a concentration camp for old people, but she contributes $14,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing seems to happen. A fellow who was a prisoner of war, who was in the Sandakan campaign, is left to rot in this nursing home by these deplorable people who run it. And the minister stands up in the House and says, `I've got no control over this.' This is a government that could not care less about old people and certainly could not care less about old people in nursing homes. There is nothing in the budget to help them. There is nothing in the budget to help those people who want to work in the community. When you see the sorts of things that have been revealed in this House in the last few days about nursing homes, the government should hang its head in shame.

There is not much in the budget for things that might raise our aspirations, like the arts, despite the government's announcement that it would continue with some programs. There is nothing for indigenous affairs. There are promises of some increased funding down the track, but how can anyone believe this government's promises? I seem to remember the Prime Minister making a promise about the GST. Promises from this government are promises that will never be kept. It will certainly not keep them merely because it has given its word to the people of Australia.

One matter that did rear its head in the budget is the sale of Telstra. As I said earlier, the budget papers refer to the deferral of the further sale of the Commonwealth's shareholding in Telstra to 2003-04, straight after the next election campaign. So much for the government's undertaking to do something about standards. It does not care what happens to standards in the bush. It is going to sell Telstra, and the standards in the bush will go down. One.Tel has shown that private telephone companies seem to go belly up. We have seen Optus sold to Singapore, and now the government will sell Telstra to whomsoever wants to buy it. People in the bush should not be conned by this lot. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: — There are not many in the parliament tonight, but perhaps there are a number of people listening to this broadcast right across Australia. I address my comments to those people who are listening tonight. I say to them: whatever your political affiliations might be, whether you have been rusted on or you are a swinging voter, step outside that for a moment and think about the clear choice that you will have at the time of the next federal election. Think about the choice that will come down to this: do you want John Howard to be Prime Minister once again, or do you want Kim Beazley to be Prime Minister? Just think about that. Do you want to have the best Prime Minister since Robert Menzies or do you want to have the worst Prime Minister since Arthur Calwell?

speech.para: Step outside even that kind of rhetoric and think about what the opposition are promising. They are promising roll-back of the GST, they are promising increases in spending in health and education, and they are promising a bigger surplus. Think about that, all those listeners out there. How would you do that in your own home budget? How would you cut your income, increase your spending and have more money in your bank account at the end of the day? How could you do that? The answer is you cannot—you absolutely cannot. But that is what you are being offered by Kim Beazley in response to the government's budget this year. The code is, of course: where are the taxes going to go up? What programs are going to be cut?

Many of you will have seen the Sunday program, where Kim Beazley was asked by Laurie Oakes, `Mr Beazley, which taxes are you going to increase? Are you going to increase that? Are you going to increase something else?' Kim Beazley's response was that it was undignified to ask him that. How could that be? How could a Leader of the Opposition who aspires to be Prime Minister of this country say, in front of the country, `I'm not going to answer that question'? Those people who are listening out there tonight, think about that. You think about why the Labor Party hides behind a comment that it is undignified to answer the question.

You have also got to think about this. As the economy grows—and it has been growing at record levels under this government— the forward estimates in the budget show that tax collection is going to fall. By the end of the fourth year it will have fallen by about $3 billion. Now think about this. The Leader of the Opposition has said that there are going to be no increases in taxes. But what he is actually saying is that there is going to be no increase in tax as a percentage of GDP. Those in this House will understand that. And what does that mean? It means that the shortfall of $3 billion which will occur is going to have to be picked up by an actual increase in taxation. And where is it going to come from? It is going to come from higher income earners and increases in company tax. Small business people out there who are listening tonight ought to understand that Kim Beazley's rhetoric is code for: we are going to do you in the eye in relation to tax. There is no doubt about that because you cannot roll back the GST, you cannot increase the spending of a government and at the same time have a bigger surplus without increasing taxation. Those who are listening tonight should certainly understand that and contemplate that. Whatever your political allegiances are, you should be mindful of that come the time of the next election, whenever that might be.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I want to remark on two issues tonight. The first is the great concern being expressed by a number of my constituents in northern Wollongong as a result of the changes being imposed by the government with the switch of the ABC to a new UHF channel 30. There are enormous difficulties being brought to bear on many of my constituents from Thirroul northwards. Quite a number of them have contacted my office and I have written to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, asking him to look at this particular matter.

speech.para: One of the things that was brought to my attention recently was that my constituents could not get through to the help line that had been put in place. Finally, when they did, they were told to contact a local technician to retune their television sets and also their video receivers. Of course, many of these people are pensioners. One of the gentlemen that contacted my office said, `A deal has been struck: he said he would come and do it for me for 20 bucks, but I just haven't got that $20 to be able to spend on something like this.' I appeal to the government to look at this issue. A number of my constituents have also said that, regrettably, they did not get the advice that the change was going to take place. It is a major issue and I bring it to the attention of the House and to the minister tonight.

The second matter I want to comment on, as this is the first opportunity that I have had, is to reinforce in this place—and these are not my words but the words of many other people—that Wollongong is now the sporting capital of Australia. I would like to lend my support and my congratulations to the Wollongong Wolves for their back-to-back victory on Sunday in defeating South Melbourne 2-1. I had the great pleasure of being at Parramatta Stadium to witness that, and it was a tremendous game of soccer and an ornament to the game. This comes hard on the heels—and I am delighted to see the member for Herbert in the chamber tonight—of the Wollongong Hawks victory in the National Basketball League title by defeating the Townsville Crocodiles.

I would like to congratulate John Carson, the owner of the Hawks, and Brendan Joyce, the coach, and all the players who have done a tremendous job in taking a team that was described as a group of battlers and turning them into a championship team. It is magnificent for the national competition that in fact two regional teams were in the grand final. Wasn't it brilliant that it was not teams coming from capital cities? I do congratulate the Hawks for a magnificent season.

I also congratulate Ron Correy, the coach of the Wollongong Wolves, all of the players and Joe Cachia and the board of directors of the Wolves for putting together a team that was able to come up with this back-to-back victory. Who could forget last year's nail-biter, where they beat Perth Glory in a penalty shoot-out? The game on Sunday was a tremendous game of football. Inspirational, as always, was Matt Horsley, the captain of the team, who won Best on Ground for the day. Matt has been playing with a deal of personal difficulty in his own life, with illness to his daughter, and we wish the family all the very best for the future. Matt is leaving to play with Perth next year, but he has been an inspirational captain. His is a Balgownie boy—I point out that I live in Balgownie as well—and he has done Wollongong proud.

I also congratulate the media of Wollongong and, indeed, all the citizens of Wollongong for getting behind the teams. They came out in force. We have done it tough over a long period of time, but we have now got two national championship teams. This says that there is another lesson to be learned there, for the Rugby League. As people would understand, we have half a team in Wollongong. We have the St George-Illawarra Dragons—half a team. Next season eight of the home games are going to be played in Wollongong. I am suggesting, now we have had the success of regional teams in the National Basketball League and in the National Soccer League, that we should have all of those games in Wollongong. The St George-Illawarra Dragons should make WIN Stadium and Wollongong their home.

We once had a proud team with the Illawarra Steelers. We were forced into amalgamations after the rugby league wars. We have a ground that is being brought up to international standard and a new grandstand is to be constructed. It is time now for the boffins in the National Rugby League to say that we need a regional team back in the Illawarra. We produce great champions, as we have over a long period of time, and in every sport you care to name now we are continuing to produce those champions. We are a champion sporting town. We know the value of sport in our local community, and it is time that the National Rugby League followed the lead of basketball and soccer and puts the Dragons in Wollongong. They will get the huge following and the success that they richly deserve. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Red Nose Day Appeal: Richmond High School

talk.start.para: —Today, the New South Wales launch of Red Nose Day 2001 occurred at Richmond High School, an excellent local school. The fact that Richmond High was chosen for this state-wide launch was, quite justifiably, a source of great pride for the school and the broader Hawkesbury community. It was a recognition of the tremendous work done by Richmond High School in recent years in supporting the annual Red Nose Day appeal, in raising community awareness of the incidence of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and in raising funds to help in its prevention.

speech.para: The record of Richmond High School in supporting the SIDS campaign has been outstanding. Last year their extraordinary fundraising efforts eclipsed previous achievements, with a total of $50,000 being raised for Red Nose Day 2000. In the 12 years that they have supported Red Nose Day, Richmond High School has raised over $150,000. By any standards this is a truly remarkable achievement. It is even more so because most of the work is done by the students themselves. The leadership of Mrs Pat Pilgrim, Principal Ken Gill, and the Student Leadership team—this year headed up by Chelsea Dewson and Daniel Morton—has provided inspiration to the whole student body and has enabled the school to achieve so much.

In addition to their impressive financial contribution to the SIDS cause, Richmond High have very effectively raised community awareness of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Their enthusiasm and passion have inspired many others in the Hawkesbury community and further afield and have drawn them into this most worthwhile cause. Also of great value is the fact that the annual Red Nose Day appeals have created within the school a culture of awareness and involvement in addressing community needs. This is generating an approach to life which is an inspiration to many and which will stay with most of the students throughout their lives—that is, a commitment to giving and to working for the good of others.

Today's launch, as I understand it, was a huge success and I would have loved to have been there. The highlight was a RAAF fly-over with six red parachutists landing right on target. The world's biggest red nose is being created by painting the school's dome-shaped assembly hall red. An exciting range of fundraising activities is already under way and a wide variety of red nose merchandise is available. Amongst other things, it includes Red Nose Day ties, such as the one I am wearing tonight, designed by year 9 student Nicole Koheghi. Congratulations, Nicole, for this fine work.
For Red Nose Day 2001, Richmond High is aiming to surpass last year's extraordinary effort of $50,000. Any donation to help the school in this superb effort would be warmly welcomed.

Sudden Infant Death Syndrome is still, tragically, the most common specific cause of death of babies between one and 12 months old in Australia. Until the national prevention campaign began in the early 1990s, an average of over 400 young lives were lost a year. Since then, with a greater awareness of the problem, the number has steadily fallen to around 180 a year. This is still far too many. Even the loss of one young life is a tragedy and the anguish and pain is almost unbearable for the parents. As a community we need to continue to do what we can to promote SIDS awareness and prevention. The work of Richmond High School in doing this is to be highly commended. My congratulations and thanks for the outstanding leadership shown by the team at Richmond High School.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight in the adjournment debate to talk about a very dear friend of mine who unfortunately passed away on Sunday, 22 April. He was none other than the Mayor of the Redlands shire, Councillor Eddie Santagiuliana. He was born in 1946 in Bolzano in northern Italy and migrated to Australia in 1955 with his late father Ferdinando and his mother Cecilia. He settled in the Redlands and became, if you like, in later life the immigrant that made good and became the leader of his community.

speech.para: Our lives were very similar. We both came out from Italy at about the same time and settled in the same area, although he joined a different party from me. He joined the party that you belong to, Mr Speaker, and then later on he joined the National Party. He was one of these sorts of fellows that really loved his community and loved the area in which he lived, and he became one of its leaders. After being at the Capalaba state school together in 1956, we parted company. I do not completely remember him from those days but I remember him from later on when we met because we were both young Italians and we could not speak the language very well. But, as we later remarked, we certainly did not do too badly in the area.

Almost 4,000 people turned out for his funeral. That would be an indication of the measure of respect for the man. He was absolutely loved by everybody. The Bayside Bulletin, the local newspaper, wrote columns and columns about him. One of the things that I will read out to you was a little story by Linda Muller in the Bayside Bulletin which is headed `The people talk ...'

quote.para: Christian Santagiuliana -

speech.para: that is his eldest son—

quote.para: says that Eddie had four children—his three sons and the shire.
And while the family choked on a deep and personal grief at the funeral of the late Mayor Eddie Santagiuliana on Friday, his fourth `child' openly mourned.

speech.para: It goes on to talk about the number of people that were there.

quote.para: Everyone's story was personal—everyone cherished their own special memory of their Mayor, their Eddie.
The funeral, the largest funeral yet to be seen in the shire, was a public display of one man's association with so many groups and individuals.

speech.para: And so it went on. But I want to particularly comment tonight on the bravery of his wife, Carolyn. They were never apart. They went to every function together, hand in hand, and they were a team. He had a fantastic family. His children—Christian, his eldest, Nicholas and his youngest son, Nathaniel—did their father proud at his funeral. It was a very emotional occasion, as you would appreciate, and he—I am sure he was looking down on them—would have been extraordinarily proud of what they did. The bravery of his wife is just something that you have to see to believe. Only a couple of days later she attended the Anzac Day dawn ceremony. She stood, in the dark, where her husband used to stand, and I had the honour of standing next to her and I let her know that I used to enjoy standing next to him as well.

We attend a lot of functions—as all my colleagues here would know—in our electorates. As much as we enjoy them, it is always good to have someone you can talk to. The person that I would always stand next to and talk to was Eddie. We would say, `Hello, paesano' which is an Italian sort of greeting. He was very close to me and I miss him very much. He just lived and breathed the shire. He was interested only in his own area. He would do anything. He would call together all the new state members and ask, `What are you going to do for our area?' Probably the best thing that I can say about him is to read out an editorial by Brian Hurst that appeared in the Redlands Times not long after his death:

quote.para: I have always tried to understand why the Redlands is such a united community.
I now know.

Much of that community focus in the Redlands came from Eddie Santagiuliana. He had the ability to harness the community spirit of the Redlands in a way that produced invaluable benefits for the community.
He was passionate about the Redlands—

speech.para: and so he went on. Eddie was a good friend, a gentle person, an honourable person, a very well-respected person. He was my friend and the friend of thousands of people around the Redlands shire. I will miss him terribly. I give my deepest sympathies to his whole family. You have lost a wonderful person and our area has lost a great champion and a great advocate. I extend my very deepest sympathies to all of his family and they will always have my support.

subdebate.1.title: Young Australian of the Year Awards

talk.start.para: —I would like to comment on the member for Bowman's tribute to Eddie Santagiuliana. He was a fine man of the shire. I share the other side of Moreton Bay, and I know that he worked tirelessly for his area in the way that was described by the member for Bowman, so I would like to pay my respects and put those words on the record as well.

speech.para: I was very pleased today to launch in Brisbane the Young Australian of the Year Awards 2002. I was launching them on behalf of the federal Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. It was a wonderful day in the sunshine at Newstead House, overlooking the Brisbane River. The reason that these awards have been set up is so that every day young people in rural areas and communities, as well as in city communities, can contribute to the future of those communities. Avenues like the Young Australian of the Year Awards give the nation the opportunity to applaud the significant contribution that young people make to our country's future. The launch today was really calling for nominations in Queensland and I was very happy to be there and to launch these very important awards. There are seven award categories and they cover areas such as arts, sport, community service, environment, career achievements in science, technology and regional initiatives. It is very important that we recognise our youth and we have had a number of incredible winners to date, including people like Poppy King, Rebecca Chalmers, Nova Peris, Tan Lee, Brian Gazela and Ian Thorpe. The Young Australian of the Year for 2001 is medical student James Fitzpatrick. He was honoured for the great work that he does, particularly in indigenous communities in the area of health.

These awards are very important. They acknowledge the hard work, excellence and dedication of our country's young achievers. The awards also mean that communities have a chance to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions in a wide range of fields important to the balanced growth of communities and the nation. The calibre of the award recipients in previous years has always been a splendid one, and young people aim high for their own personal development and also for the communities that they represent. It is their energy and creativity that ultimately will determine the future of communities throughout Australia and it is their efforts that have been significantly achieving and improving the quality of life of our regional communities—and they benefit us all here and now.

So the federal government has been very proud to be the sponsor of these awards, particularly the regional initiative and career achievement award categories. It is a golden opportunity to facilitate great things for our communities, our regions and our youth. The government has also been involved in initiatives that encourage our young people and recognise their very important contribution. For example, last week the National Youth Media Awards were announced by Dr David Kemp, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. These awards were initiated by the Howard government and they have attracted an increased number of entries. So too does the government place great store in the discussions and the outcomes of the National Youth Roundtable. These roundtables include young people from a range of backgrounds and experiences and from all states and territories, and they bring them together so that they can present a wide range of views and ideas to share with the federal government.

The federal government has also gotten very heavily involved with the very successful ABC Heywire program, which gives regional young Australians opportunities for their views to be aired on radio. The existence of programs and initiatives such as the Young Australian of the Year Awards and many of the others across the country is proof positive, if we need it, of the intense interest and commitment of so many of our young people. The government wants to make sure that the future Australia is a place in which all young Australians want to contribute and to help make a better place. That is why the government has worked in partnership with communities, industry, the private sector and all spheres of government to ensure that Australian communities remain strong and resilient in the face of the international economic environment and its subsequent impacts.

I would like to acknowledge the sponsors this year all by name: the Coffee Club; McDonald's, which is sponsoring the sports award; the KCL Group, which is sponsoring the science and technology award; and a number of other sponsors such as Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank and the Hilton. I would like to pay tribute to the sponsors. I was very pleased to play a part in the official launch today of the Young Australian of the Year Awards.

talk.start.para: —I rise in the parliament to honour the 125th anniversary of the Belmont State School, celebrated in Brisbane today, 5 June 2001. Accompanying that anniversary were significant celebratory activities at the school in which all the children of the school participated. In 1875 the land on which the school now stands was part of a farm named Belmont, which was owned by one August Carl Bernecker. He had children who were of school age and he organised a meeting of local farmers with a view to petitioning the Board of Education to build a school on the corner of Scrub and Old Cleveland Roads. Mr Bernecker offered two acres of his land, along with £61 9s 6d, which had been collected from local residents. On 4 October 1875, the Board of Education signed an agreement to pay £440 to a building contractor for the construction of a schoolroom, a teacher's residence and schoolroom furniture. On 5 June 1876, the school opened with an enrolment of 38 pupils. Average attendance in the first year was 47 pupils, and the head teacher was one Mr William Jennings.

speech.para: A lot has happened in the intervening century. In 1975 the school celebrated its centenary and its original enrolments of some 20 or 30 had by that stage risen to some 250, with 10 teachers on staff and with Mr G.W.T. Beverley as the school's 25th principal in 100 years of operation. Today the school at Belmont is under the management of principal Peter Prentice, who has been a fine and excellent principal of the school since 1990, and vice-principals Valmai Nolan and Jane Tuckett. The enrolment today, starting from those original 30 or so students, is now some 911. Its enrolments in languages other than English, which in the case of Belmont means Japanese, cover some 363 students—a very important contribution to the study of foreign languages in Brisbane's and Queensland's school system.

The P&C Association is at present under the presidency of Brett Blade, its vice-presidents Mark Thomson and Anne McCarthy, secretary Margaret Blade and treasurer Scott Kilvington. The 125 Year Fete Convenors were Anne McCarthy, Jenny Reedman and Lisa Kalanjis, and it was my privilege to attend that fete last Sunday and see the extraordinary contribution which had been made by members of the fete committee to a very successful event.

As for the centenary-plus celebrations, a 125 Years Work Team was formed in the year 2000 and comprises the following members: Valmai Nolan, Geoff Lines, Coralie Rogers, Jane Tuckett, Sharon Joel, Wendy McGregor, Rita Paine, Kaylene Bell, Sue Butler, Val Heinke, Tracey Knight-Turvey, Cathy Costello, Jenny Reedman and Barbara Green. These individuals, with support from other participants in the work of the 125 Years Work Team, all contributed to the important celebratory activities which were held at the Belmont State School today. Those celebratory activities involved a range of events, including a presentation on the school's history by School Captain Mitchell Enright and a range of choral renditions. There was also a roll call of students from 1915 to 1949. We had a presentation on the school's future by Jessica Gunawan, who is also a 2001 school captain, other choral renditions and presentations of choral poetry by classes 4B, 4L, 4M, 4N and 4T. I commend the school on this important anniversary—125 years. The school has achieved great things and I salute the Belmont State School, its management and the entire school community on reaching this important milestone.

On 30 May, I attended the Dominican Justice Focus Breakfast at San Sisto College in the suburb of Carina in my electorate. talk.start.para: —I wish to call the attention of the House to the very great success of the small inland city of Mount Isa, as Paul Bowman and Nathan Fien have both made the State of Origin team. Both are sons of very famous local footballers. They have led us on many occasions to great victories in the North Queensland competition, the famous Foley Shield competition. I am sure they are very proud fathers, but we people of north-west Queensland are all very proud of those two young men. The city that produced Pat Rafter and Greg Norman can, of course, boast very great success in the area of sport.

speech.para: I also want to bring the attention of the House tonight to the most serious plight that has arisen in the banana industry. The banana industry is one of the biggest employers in this country, with probably 6,000 or 7,000 direct jobs involved in the industry. It produces between $200 million and $300 million worth of produce a year. It is an entirely Australian industry; there are no imports of bananas into Australia. The reason that there are no imports of bananas into Australia is that every other banana producing country on earth is rife with a large number of endemic diseases, which we desperately do not want and do not need in this country. It must be understood that, when you import fruit and vegetables into this country, with those fruit and vegetables invariably come fungi and microbes of a very pernicious nature; these organisms will inevitably come into this country.

The work of AQIS over a long period of time has been a disgusting black mark upon the procedures of government throughout the last 15 years. We people in North Queensland have suffered most, with some $72 million worth of damage from the papaya fruit fly; probably another $15 million will be lost as a result of black sigatoka, which has broken out in North Queensland. A lot of these diseases are endemic in the Indonesian archipelago area and in New Guinea—some of them even into the Torres Strait. Eighty-five or 95 per cent of everything that comes out of the Torres Strait can be quarantined at the Horn Island airport and at the Jardine ferry. At the time of giving this address, neither of those points is being inspected. There are six inspectors on Thursday Island; but, as far as the Jardine ferry is concerned, all you have to do is pay the ferryman and you have almost a complete protection mechanism! Black sigatoka has got in. It is thought—once again, like the papaya fruit fly—that it has come in via the Torres Strait. There are a large number of other explanations, but that is one of them.

In the same two-month period that AQIS decided to allow grapes from California into this country, there was a two-page article in the national magazine the Bulletin on the collapse of the grape growing industry in California, the destruction of one-tenth of the entire industry by Pierce's disease, which is carried by a vector insect called the glassy-winged sharpshooter. That article came out in the two-month period in which AQIS decided to allow grapes from that area into Australia.

I am not going to canvass tonight the issue of apple importation; it does not pertain to my area, and many other people have spoken at great length on it. If this country wants to maintain a clean, green image, then AQIS had better forget about its commitment to free trade, because it seems to be a vehicle for imposing the policies of free trade upon this country rather than a vehicle to protect this country against the introduction of pernicious diseases. We have had outbreaks of fire blight in the apple industry, we have had outbreaks of papaya fruit fly and now black sigatoka, and we ask ourselves, `What are these people doing?'

If that is not bad enough in itself, if you want to know what AQIS are doing, look no further than the grape decision or the durian decision. Our mangoes are not allowed in the United States; we have a seed weevil. They just say, `You can't come in; you've got a seed weevil.' We allow durians in from Thailand; Thailand has a seed weevil. AQIS had better decide whether they are a department implementing the policies of free trade or whether they are a department trying to protect this country—not only our productive environment but also our natural environment, which is under threat from introduced species. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 February 2001:

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No sales tax is payable on the purchase of a motorcycle. Wholesale sales tax was abolished following the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000. However, GST is payable on the purchase of a motorcycle.
(2) Yes.

(3) From 1 July 2000, veterans in receipt of disability pension at the Special Rate who had been eligible for sales tax exemption on motor vehicles became eligible under section 38-505 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services) Tax Act 1999 to exemption from GST in respect to the purchase of a `car'. (8) Did the Joint Chiefs of Staff agree in April 1998 to the establishment of a proposed specialist career and salary structure for Defence medical officers; if so, what was the reason for this decision.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b)
(2) (a) Surgeons
(b) Anaesthetists
(c) Other Specialists
(c) Nil
(4) Civil Practice Support Allowance is payable to all self-employed Reserve specialist medical officers who deploy on overseas operations.
(5) For the period 1 July 2000 - 28 March 2001

(6) Yes. Health Policy Directive (HPD) 906 - Fees Payable for Services Rendered by Civilian Medical, Dental and Allied Health Practitioners provides a guideline for remuneration on a State by State basis and varies according to the cost of living and other constraints that may be imposed on health practitioners. HPD 906 was last updated in January 2001.

(7) The Study into the Attraction and Retention of Medical and Dental Officers in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) by the retired Surgeon General, Major General D G Rossi, was completed in January 1997. It made 62 separate recommendations. Over 50% of these recommendations have been implemented. Many of the others have been subsumed into other major projects such as JP 2060 - Deployable Health Support, the Specialist Officer Career Structure and the Specialist Officer Salary Structure. Other recommendations have been overtaken by events, are considered no longer relevant or did not attract universal acceptance by the Services.

(8) In Agendum 8/98, on 17 March 1998 the Chiefs of Staff Committee (COSC) acknowledged that the current career and salary structure for medical officers no longer met the aspirations of young, newly qualified medical graduates. Both recruitment and retention had deteriorated significantly and, at that time, there was a 30% shortage of uniformed medical officers. COSC agreed to the implementation of a Specialist Officer Salary Structure (SOSS), for officers employed for specific specialist duty, as part of the ADF Pay Structure Review.

To be effective, remuneration structures should be closely linked to the full range of conditions of employment. Remuneration forms only part of the total employment package and should support, and be supported by, a range of other measures. These include, but are not limited to, career progression, training and professional development. Accordingly, it was decided to develop a Specialist Officer Career Structure for those specialist officer categories being examined under SOSS.

(9) Defence remains committed to achieving a new medical officers' career and salary structure. Several important factors have led to the delay of the realisation of this proposal. Firstly, East Timor deployments took the focus away. Secondly, Defence was awaiting the release of the White Paper, which was to give direction on capabilities, including JP2060 - Deployable Health Capability. Until JP2060 identified the number of medical officers we required to provide deployable health support it was impossible to design a sustainable career structure. Defence has moved the milestone of presentation to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal out to accommodate the realities of this difficult and complex issue. To do otherwise would be to risk the integrity of the review process and compromise the business case for a revised career and salary structure.

(10) The External Review into Remuneration currently led by Major General Nunn is due to report to Government on 31 August 2001. It is highly unlikely that any cases will be put forward to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal until the Government has considered the recommendations and further direction given.

(11) Many major Defence Health Service units have entered into a wide variety of agreements with civilian health facilities to allow Defence Health personnel to develop the skills they require to support operational deployments. These range from medical and nursing officers and medical assistants working in the accident and emergency departments of major Sydney teaching hospitals to medical assistants working with metropolitan ambulance services. Each agreement is tailored to suit local circumstances and many have been varied recently due to the increase in operational tempo created by concurrent deployments to Bougainville and East Timor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

question.para: (1) Will he provide the Parliament with an analysis of the fuel consumption of the current Australian passenger and light vehicle fleet.
(2) Is it the case that the fuel consumption of Australia's passenger and light vehicle fleet is among the worst, if not the worst, in the OECD.

(4) Are the high prices that motorists pay for petrol compounded by the fact that their vehicles waste 80% or more of the energy contained in the fuel.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The motor vehicle industry reports annually against an agreed National Average Fuel Consumption (NAFC) target for new passenger cars. The NAFC target is included in an industry voluntary code of practice. The most recent (2000) target figure for NAFC was set at 8.2 litres/100km. The Government is working with the motor vehicle industry to set a NAFC target 15% below business as usual for 2010.

(2) It is difficult to compare the fuel consumption across different countries due to the different assessment methods used. As part of the process of global harmonisation across the motor vehicle industry, the Government is planning on introducing a new Australian Design Rule (ADR) to come into force in 2003 that will mandate a new fuel consumption testing procedure in line with international standards.
(3) Yes.

(4) The thermal efficiency of the internal combustion engine is the constraint within which all conventionally powered vehicles operate. However through the fuel consumption label and fuel consumption guide consumers are being educated that they can reduce the cost and environmental impact of road transport through the selection of more fuel efficient vehicles.
(5) The level of greenhouse emissions is directly related to the quantity of fuel consumed by a vehicle.

(6) The Government has introduced a range of initiatives, to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector as outlined in the Prime Minister's statement: Safeguarding the Future announced in 1997 and Measures for a Better Environment in 1999. Key elements:
· 15 % improvement over business as usual to the National Average Fuel Consumption(NAFC) target by 2010;
· Introduction of the fuel consumption label, as of 1 January 2001;
· Improved fuel quality standards; and
· Promotion of alternative fuels.

(7) Yes. The Australian Greenhouse Office estimates that the introduction of mandatory fuel consumption labelling would result in savings of approximately 800,000 tonnes per annum of greenhouse gas emissions in 2010.
The Australian Greenhouse Office advises that estimates have not been finalised.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to provide an analysis of the energy consumption and carbon dioxide levels of the transport sector.

(2) Has the transport sector had the highest rate of growth of carbon dioxide emissions in the Australian economy; if so, what is the cause of this rapid increase and what measures has the Government adopted to stem this growth.
(3) Has much of this increase come from the growth in road transport, in particular, road freight, that has taken place at the expense of rail transport.

(4) Is diesel hauled rail transport at least four times as energy efficient as road transport and consequently emits one quarter as much carbon dioxide per tonne-kilometre, as reported by the Australian Railway Association.
(5) Is electric railway haulage 40% more efficient again than diesel-hauled rail transport and emits even less carbon dioxide per tonne kilometre, as reported by international railway operators.
(6) Has he stated in the past that his first priority is for road transport and rail comes a distant second.

(7) Is it the policy of the Government to force down apparent transport costs by allowing the road freight industry to be carried by low paid owner drivers who can barely afford the cost of fuel let alone proper maintenance.

(8) Does the road transport industry receive subsidies in the form of free fuel, un-recovered road construction and repair costs and services that equals or exceeds 90% of their operating expenses, as reported by the Bureau of Transport Economics.
(9) If so, will the Government act to recover a higher proportion of these costs and so improve the competitiveness of the much more energy efficient railways.

(10) Is it a fact that (a) Federal funding has not been made available for the construction of new urban rail systems in NSW and (b) billions of dollars been made available or promised for the construction of new urban road works such as the Western Sydney Orbital.

(11) What is the estimate of the reductions in carbon dioxide emissions in kilograms per dollar invested resulting in improvements in travel efficiency for the Western Sydney Orbital compared with the proposed but un-funded Epping to Castle Hill Railway.
(12) Is he able to supply estimates for the quantity of carbon dioxide emitted for an equivalent distance travelled by a commuter using (a) a private car, (b) an electric train and (c) a bicycle.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (2), and (3) The National Greenhouse Gas Inventory contains the requested information. The Government has a range of measures in place or planned to address carbon dioxide emissions from the transport sector as detailed in the answer to Question no 2522.

(4) Rail can be more energy efficient than road for some transport tasks eg long distance heavy freight. The Bureau of Transport Economics estimates that on average, rail produces one third of the carbon dioxide emissions of road freight per tonne kilometre.

(5) Electric railway haulage can produce considerably less carbon dioxide emissions than diesel-hauled rail transport, if either hydro or nuclear power is the source of the electricity. However, if the electricity is sourced from coal-powered generators, then emissions from electric rail haulage could be higher than those from diesel-hauled rail. Once generation and transmission are taken into account, carbon dioxide emissions per unit of energy can be considerably higher for electric rail than for diesel-powered rail.
(8) and (9) No. The Bureau of Transport Economics advises that none of its research suggest 90% under recovery.
(10a) The Commonwealth has a $250m mainline rail track upgrade program which is improving the performance of this key national infrastructure.
(10b) The Western Sydney Orbital (WSO) will be privately constructed and operated, and financed largely by a user toll. The Commonwealth will make a total contribution of $356m to the project.
(11) The WSO Environmental Impact Statement does not address the question of carbon dioxide reductions. The proposed Epping to Castle Hill Railway is the responsibility of the NSW Government.

(12) Current BTE estimates indicate that the fleet average performance for Australian cars is 250 grams of carbon dioxide equivalent per passenger kilometre. Per passenger emissions from electric trains depends critically on the source of the electricity and load factor of the train, however, an average rate would be 120 grams of carbon dioxide equivalent per passenger kilometre. Bicycle use generates no emissions.
